{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox event |Event_Name = 2011 Haimen protest |image = Haimen1.jpg |caption = The first power plant in Haimen. Concerns about the construction of a second such plant sparked the December 2011 protests and riots. |AKA = Haimen Incident |Participants = People in Haimen Town ([[Teochew people]]) |Location = [[Haimen, Guangdong|Haimen]], [[Shantou]], Guangdong, People's Republic of China |Date = December 2011 |Result = Project is suspended |URL = }} The '''2011 Haimen protest''' of December 2011 occurred in the Chinese town of [[Haimen, Guangdong|Haimen]], [[Guangdong province]]. The protests, which drew thousands of participants, were met with detentions and tear gassing by authorities.<ref name=NYT>Michael Wines, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/24/world/asia/china-jails-rights-activist-chen-wei-for-9-years.html?_r=3 Police Fire Tear Gas at Protesters in Chinese City], New York Times, 23 December 2011.</ref>
Protests were ignited over plans to expand a coal-fired power plant in the town—a plan that residents opposed, arguing that existing coal-fired plants had caused environmental and health damage.<ref name=NYT/><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/zhongwen/simp/chinese_news/2011/12/111220_haimen_protest.shtml 广东海门逾万民众抗议反对建电厂] BBC中文網，2011年12月20日</ref> Demonstrations began on Tuesday, 20 December when thousands of residents barricaded a freeway and surrounded government offices in an attempt to block the project.<ref name=NYT/>
According to AFP, the riot police fired tear gas into the crowd and beat protesters with riot sticks.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iZA9mo9YrWEbDFUhj-4_QNjh8fvg?docId=CNG.26ca44d2792efc30a1d45b7e1da3908a.251 Police in China fire tear-gas, beat protesters: witnesses] Google News:AFP，20 December 2011</ref> Late on 20 December, the state-run [[Xinhua News Agency]] said that five residents had been detained on vandalism charged, and published a declaration from the Shantou city council announcing that the "Shantou deputy and municipality already decided to stop the project.<ref>[http://www.chinapress.com.my/node/278881 華電發電項目暫停] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419022028/http://www.chinapress.com.my/node/278881 |date=19 April 2012 }} 中國報，20 December 2011: 「汕頭市委、市政府已決定暫停上馬這一項目」</ref><ref>《[https://web.archive.org/web/20120109032522/http://www.dahuawang.com/strb/html/2011-12/21/content_277192.htm 市委、市政府妥善处置潮阳区海门镇部分群众堵塞深汕高速公路的行为]》(汕頭日報，2011/12/21)</ref> Unconfirmed reports of two deaths circulated online following the first day of protests, though authorities denied these reports.<ref name=Reuters>Reuters, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/21/china-protest-plant-idUSL3E7NL0KR20111221 Chinese official denies reports of deaths at Haimen protest], 21 December 2011.</ref>
Tensions cooled by 23 December, after [[Communist Party of China|Communist Party]] officials declared that the plant expansion plans would be temporarily suspended, and authorities agreed to release detained protesters.<ref>Agence France Presse, [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iA8Bsv0H3uV5csLrwZpvqjvJbsgA?docId=CNG.1b4291d697ee9c20c9e8e44453865af5.361 South China town unrest cools after dialogue], 23 Dec 2011.</ref>
Although the protests in Haimen were unrelated to demonstrations in nearby [[Protests of Wukan|Wukan]], Haimen residents told Reuters that they had followed developments in Wukan closely, regarding it as a good model of how citizens might negotiate with authorities.<ref name=Reuters/>
== See also == * [[Protest of Wukan]] * [[List of civil disturbances in the People's Republic of China (2011)]]

Mircea Olaru {{small|(Chief of the [[Romanian Gendarmerie]])}} | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | injuries = | fatalities = | arrests = | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = }} The '''2012–15 unrest in [[Romania]]''' refers to a prolonged period of [[civil unrest]] and political scandals in Romania, which took magnitude after the second half of the 2000s. The wave of civil demonstrations started in January 2012, once with the introduction of a new health reform legislation. The protests were fueled by the austerity measures applied in May 2010, but also by the unpopularity of [[Traian Băsescu|Băsescu]]-backed [[Boc Cabinets|Boc government]]. The demonstrations were characterized by widespread rioting and acts of vandalism. The political situation precipitated, so Prime Minister [[Emil Boc]] decided to step down on 6 February 2012. In the first six months of the year, three governments have been changed. The summer of 2012 was marked by a large-scale [[2012 Romanian political crisis|political crisis]], fed by [[Victor Ponta#Plagiarism controversy|accusations of plagiarism]] to PSD-backed Prime Minister [[Victor Ponta]] and culminating with the suspension of President [[Traian Băsescu]]. Although the [[Romanian presidential impeachment referendum, 2012|presidential impeachment referendum]] showed that over 80% of the voters wanted his dismissal, the referendum was invalidated by the [[Constitutional Court of Romania|Constitutional Court]] due to presence below 50% at polls. During this period, Romania was warned by Western powers about the state of democracy, inasmuch as the dismissal of the presidents of the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies was made in a shady manner, and prominent figures of PSD, including Vice-President [[Liviu Dragnea]], were accused of vote rigging in the referendum. After sweeping victory in [[Romanian legislative election, 2012|legislative election on 9 December 2012]], Victor Ponta – supported by the [[Social Liberal Union]] – was named [[Prime Minister of Romania]]. His mandate was marked by corruption scandals and street protests. The demonstrations had various causes, among them the tax hikes, the exploitation of [[shale gas]] through [[hydraulic fracturing]] and the [[Roșia Montană Project]]. Hundreds of thousands of people, including doctors, teachers, students and laborers, took to the street to shout their dissatisfaction regarding his policies. Employees in transport and health system triggered several strikes in this period. Although mainly peaceful, the protests degenerated in some cases in clashes between demonstrators and law enforcers. Ponta Government was accused by national and international organizations of excessive use of force in the [[2012–14 Romanian protests against shale gas#Revolt of Pungești|Revolt of Pungești]]. Ethnic Hungarians started a series of protests for the autonomy of [[Szeklerland]], while the unionist movements (see ''[[Unification of Romania and Moldova|Action 2012]]'') demanded the [[unification of Romania and Moldova]], both in Romania and over the [[Prut]]. In the winter of 2014, the ruling alliance collapsed, after internal tensions between PSD and PNL. The [[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party]] left the alliance and merged with the [[Democratic Liberal Party (Romania)|Democratic Liberal Party]] to form the largest right-wing party in Romania in the post-revolutionary period. In the summer of the same year, [[Victor Ponta]] from PSD and [[Klaus Iohannis]] from PNL launched their candidatures for the [[Romanian presidential election, 2014|presidential election]]. To everyone's surprise, ethnic German [[Klaus Iohannis]] won the election. Ponta's failure was mainly due to irregularities concerning the voting process in diaspora and numerous corruption scandals involving figures from the party he leads. During the electoral campaign, people protested against Victor Ponta and members of his government, inasmuch as thousands of Romanian citizens in diaspora were prevented from exercising their right to vote due to bad organization of the election process.{{cite web |url=http://www.gandul.info/voteaza/mesajul-romanilor-din-diaspora-demisia-lui-ponta-reconstruirea-romaniei-depinde-de-noi-toti-iohannis-a-primit-girul-dar-suntem-cu-ochii-pe-el-13578118 |title=Mesajul românilor din diaspora: "Demisia Lui Ponta. Reconstruirea României depinde de noi toți. Iohannis a primit girul, dar suntem cu ochii pe el" |work=Gândul |date=17 November 2014 |author =Sorina Ionașc |language=Romanian}} == Background == === Social issues === Romania is the country with the highest poverty levels in the [[European Union]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nineoclock.ro/romania-the-country-with-the-highest-poverty-levels-in-the-eu/ |title=Romania, the country with the highest poverty levels in the EU |newspaper=Nine O'Clock |author =Anca Bernovici |date=12 May 2013}} More than 30% of the population lives on less than $5 per day. In a report conducted by the Presidential Commission for the Analysis of Social and Demographic Risks is specified that there are visible discrepancies between social strata, privileged groups benefiting of higher wages and pensions in comparison with the rest of the population.{{cite web |url=http://www.presidency.ro/static/CPARSDR_raport_extins.pdf |title=Riscuri și inechități sociale în România |work=Presidential Administration |date=September 2009 |language=Romanian}} Bankruptcy of many companies thickens the unemployment rate, in July 2013 reaching the value of 7.6%, highest since onset of the [[Great Recession in Europe|economic crisis]] in 2010.{{cite news |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/nivel-record-al-somajului-in-ultimii-ani-cati-someri-sunt-in-romania-11184401 |title=Nivel RECORD al șomajului în ultimii ani. Câți șomeri sunt în România |newspaper=Mediafax |author =Aurelia Alexa |date=31 July 2013 |language=Romanian}} Other companies, including state companies – [[Poșta Română|Romanian Post]], [[Căile Ferate Române|Romanian Railways]], are on the verge of bankruptcy, being forced to make cutbacks. After application of drastic austerity measures in 2010, the Romanian economy recovered. Thus, in 2013, Romania recorded the highest economic growth in the EU.{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/101205409 |title='Tiger' of Eastern Europe is waking up: Romanian PM |newspaper=CNBC |author =Holly Ellyatt |date=18 November 2013}} Despite this growth, the [[standard of living]] is decreasing,{{cite web |url=http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/cache/ITY_OFFPUB/KS-SF-13-008/EN/KS-SF-13-008-EN.PDF |title=Living standards falling in most Member States |work=Eurostat}} many Romanians being unable to endure everyday expenses. Poor working conditions, mass layoffs and tax hikes displease the population that is filling the squares of main cities to shout their grievances. === Political turmoil === Over the past 25 years, Romania has experienced a complex process of democratization with moments of crisis, economic stagnation, radical nationalism and extreme polarization.{{cite book |last1=Bunce |first1=Valerie |last2=Wolchik |first2=Sharon |date=October 2006 |title=Favorable Conditions and Electoral Revolutions |url=http://www.journalofdemocracy.org/article/favorable-conditions-and-electoral-revolutions |publisher=Journal of Democracy |pages=5–18}}{{cite book |last=Soare |first=Sorina |date=2011 |title=Bulgaria e Romania, vent'anni dopo: il peso del passato, le sfide del presente |trans-title=Bulgaria and Romania, two decades later: the weight of the past, the challenges of the present |url=https://www.academia.edu/1030094/Bulgaria_e_Romania_ventanni_dopo_il_peso_del_passato_le_sfide_del_presente |language=Italian |location=Bologna |publisher=Il Mulino}} Despite [[Romania–NATO relations|Romania's admission into NATO in 2004]], and [[2007 enlargement of the European Union|into the European Union in 2007]], the political situation remained unstable, with recurrent institutional clashes between the President, Prime Minister and Parliament, such as in 2007 and 2012{{cite book |last1=Gherghina |first1=Sergiu |last2=Mișcoiu |first2=Sergiu |date=2013 |title=The Failure of Cohabitation: The Institutional Crises in Romania |url=http://eep.sagepub.com/content/early/2013/05/13/0888325413485621.full.pdf |publisher=East European Politics and Societies |pages=668–684}} and tough austerity measures that fuelled social tensions. == Timeline of the events == === Mid-January 2012 riots === {{Main|2012 Romanian protests}} {{ external media | float = right | width = | image1 = [https://www.flickr.com/photos/yahooeditorspicks/galleries/72157628943388675 Romania Protests 2012] on [[Flickr]] | image2 = [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-16592719 Romanian protests: In pictures] on [[BBC]] | image3 = [http://www.mediafax.ro/social/galerie-foto-imagini-din-a-treia-zi-de-proteste-in-bucuresti-9149074/foto/ GALERIE FOTO – Imagini din a treia zi de proteste în București] on [[Mediafax]] | video1 = {{YouTube|id=nERnBGcPwKM|title=Molotov cocktails vs tear gas: New wave of Romania violence}} | video2 = {{YouTube|id=Difi2rzsGTk|title=Romania clashes video: Anti-cuts protests turn violent in Bucharest}} | video3 = {{YouTube|id=kOVuhqZBRac|title='We want him out': Anger burning in Romania}} }} These were the first events of the two-year civil unrest. They were triggered by the introduction of a new health reform legislation and worsening standard of life. President [[Traian Băsescu]]'s popularity collapsed mainly after imposing austerity measures in 2010, year when Romania also confronted with short living but large street demonstrations. The attempted privatization of [[SMURD]] and the denigration by Traian Băsescu of [[Raed Arafat]], its founder, was vehemently criticized by people on the streets.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-16570860 |title=Romania protests: PM Emil Boc calls for dialogue |newspaper=BBC News |date=16 January 2012}} [[File:2012-01-15-Romanian-protests-in-Bucgarest.jpg|thumb|left|Large demonstration in Bucharest, on 15 January]] The protests started with a 3,000-large demonstration in [[Târgu Mureș]] on 12 January, as a sign of solidarity with Raed Arafat.{{cite web |url=http://www.rfi.ro/articol/stiri/social/manifestatie-sustinere-doctorului-arafat-targu-mures |title=Manifestație de susținere a doctorului Arafat la Târgu Mureș |work=Radio France Internationale |date=13 January 2012 |language=Romanian}} In the following weeks, protests spread to other sixty Romanian cities and dozens of cities in the [[Romanian diaspora]].{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/01/15/world/europe/romania-protests/ |title=Protesters gather for fourth straight day in Romania |work=CNN |author =Liliana Ciobanu |date=15 January 2014}} In [[Bucharest]], the largest protest took place on 19 January, when up to 20,000 people expressed their disagreements with Băsescu regime. Several days, Bucharest faced widespread rioting and acts of vandalism. Thousands of policemen and gendarmes were deployed on the streets to confront angry demonstrators that stoned the vehicles of the law enforcers, vandalized shops and burned cars. Riot police used tear gas and flares to repel demonstrators who blocked traffic in the center of Bucharest.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/16/world/europe/romanians-protest-austerity-measures.html?_r=0 |title=Protests Over Austerity Measures Turn Violent in Romania |newspaper=The New York Times |date=15 January 2012}} According to the Gendarmerie, destructions were caused by football ultras infiltrated among peaceful demonstrators.{{cite news |url=http://observers.france24.com/content/20120116-unrest-romania-violent-rioters-fight-peaceful-protester-demonstration-bucharest-basescu-health-care-austerity |title=Unrest in Bucharest: protesters say a minority of violent rioters were 'out for a fight' |newspaper=France 24 |date=16 January 2012}} During these days of turmoil, several protesters entered the [[Romanian Television]] headquarters to blame the broadcaster for [[media censorship|censorship]]. Official figures indicated over 60 injuries during clashes between police and protesters, while up to 283 arrests were made.{{cite news |url=http://www.evz.ro/jandarmeria-283-de-manifestanti-au-fost-dusi-la-politie-opt-dintre-ei-sunt-din-galeria-p-961707.html |title=Jandarmeria: 283 de manifestanți, duși la Poliție. Opt dintre ei sunt din galeria Petrolului |newspaper=Evenimentul Zilei |author1=Antoaneta Etves |author2=Ionela Săvescu |date=16 January 2012 |language=Romanian}} Several journalists were injured while transmitting live the events. [[South East Europe Media Organisation]], a NGO that has its headquarters in [[Vienna]], expressed concern about the level of violence against reporters who covered the protests.{{cite news |url=http://www.ziare.com/stiri/proteste/presa-straina-jurnalisti-atacati-si-batuti-in-timpul-protestelor-din-romania-1147489 |title=Presa străină: Jurnaliști atacați și bătuți în timpul protestelor din România |newspaper=Ziare.com |author =Florin Necula |date=27 January 2012 |language=Romanian}} On the morning of 6 February 2012, Prime Minister [[Emil Boc]] announced his resignation, in an attempt "to ease the social situation".{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/feb/06/romanian-pm-emil-boc-resigns |title=Romanian prime minister Emil Boc resigns |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 February 2012}} During weeks of protests, Băsescu stated nothing and didn't appear in public. Emil Boc was replaced by [[Mihai Răzvan Ungureanu]], former Director of the [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Romania)|Foreign Intelligence Service]].{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/romanias-newly-appointed-pm-names-government-102412258.html |title=Romania's newly appointed PM names his government |work=Yahoo! News |date=8 February 2012}} === 2012 political crisis === {{Main|2012 Romanian constitutional crisis|l1=2012 Romanian political crisis}} [[File:My name is Paste. Copy Paste, proteste Victoria 9-7-12.JPG|thumb|Protest against Victor Ponta in Victory Square, Bucharest. The placard reads ''My name is Paste. Copy Paste'' – a satire of Ponta as a plagiarist. The phrase was coined by ''[[The Economist]]'' and became widely used among Ponta's opponents.]] Soon after government led by [[Mihai Răzvan Ungureanu]] fell in [[motion of no confidence|no confidence vote]], [[Victor Ponta]] took in office. Ponta is an ardent Băsescu's opponent. In June 2012, they were the protagonists of a major political crisis, starting with conflicting views on Romania's representative to the [[European Council]] reunion of 28 June and escalating with the suspension of President Traian Băsescu.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/07/us-romania-politics-idUSBRE86609I20120707 |title=Germany, U.S: Romania power struggle hurts democracy |newspaper=Reuters |date=7 July 2012}} In the same period, Prime Minister Victor Ponta was accused of plagiarism in his doctoral thesis.{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/19/victor-ponta-plagiarism-romania-prime-minister_n_1609410.html |title=Victor Ponta, Romania Prime Minister, Accused of Plagiarism in Doctoral Thesis |newspaper=The Huffington Post |author =Alison Mutler |date=19 June 2012}} These accusations fed the political instability.{{cite web |url=http://www.romaniatv.net/reuters-acuzatiile-de-plagiat-la-adresa-lui-ponta-alimenteaza-instabilitatea-in-romania_34369.html |title=Reuters: Acuzațiile de plagiat la adresa lui Ponta alimentează INSTABILITATEA în România |work=România TV |date=29 June 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[File:Mangalioţi, protest Piaţa Revoluţiei 26-7-12.jpg|thumb|left|People arriving with buses at a protest in [[Revolution Square, Bucharest|Revolution Square]], Bucharest, on 26 July 2012]] On 3 July, the Romanian Parliament, at the proposal of majority represented by [[Social Liberal Union]], voted the dismissal of [[President of the Senate of Romania|President of the Senate]] and [[President of the Chamber of Deputies of Romania|President of the Chamber of Deputies]].{{cite news |url=http://www.capital.ro/usl-cere-revocarea-din-functie-a-robertei-anastase-si-a-lui-vasile-blaga-168644.html |title=USL cere revocarea din funcție a Robertei Anastase și a lui Vasile Blaga |newspaper=Capital |date=3 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} Through an Emergency Ordinance, the government restricted the attributions of the [[Constitutional Court of Romania|Constitutional Court]], restoring them to the 2010 status. Likewise, USL leaders Victor Ponta and Crin Antonescu started procedures to dismiss President Traian Băsescu. These measures irritated the international politicians which expressed concerns over the state of democracy and the rule of law in Romania.{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/eu-concerned-over-romanian-parliament-impeachment-of-president-basescu-a-843382.html |title=The World from Berlin: A 'Humiliating Show Trial' in Romania |newspaper=Der Spiegel |date=9 July 2012}} On 6 July, Băsescu was suspended after the impeachment motion filed by the ruling coalition passed the Parliament's vote.{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/06/world/europe/romania-impeachment/index.html |title=Romanian president suspended |work=CNN |author =Liliana Ciobanu |date=7 July 2012}} The motion passed with 256 votes, 39 more than the minimum required.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-18742734 |title=Romanian parliament votes to suspend President Băsescu |work=BBC News |date=6 July 2012}} USL leaders argued their action by saying that President Traian Băsescu has breached the Constitution and overstepped his authority. On 9 July, the Constitutional Court ascertained President Băsescu's suspension and confirmed [[Crin Antonescu]] as Interim President.{{cite news |url=http://english.hotnews.ro/stiri-top_news-12753163-romania-39-constitutional-court-decides-procedure-suspend-president-basescu-was-constitutional-crin-antonescu-becomes-interim-president.htm |title=Romania's Constitutional Court decides procedure to suspend President Băsescu was constitutional. Crin Antonescu becomes interim president |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author =V.O. |date=9 July 2012}} Therewith, Constitutional Court rejected complaints formulated by [[Vasile Blaga]] and [[Roberta Anastase]], supported by [[Democratic Liberal Party (Romania)|PDL]], regarding removal from office of President of the Senate and President of the Chamber of Deputies.{{cite web |url=http://www.romaniatv.net/ccr-revocarile-lui-vasile-blaga-si-a-robertei-anastase-constitutionale_35447.html |title=CCR: Revocările lui Vasile Blaga și a Robertei Anastase, constituționale |work=România TV |date=9 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} On 20 July, USL laid down, at the Office of the High Court of Cassation and Justice, a penal complaint against suspended President Traian Băsescu and other 14 people, for "spreading false information, for defamation of the country and the nation and for endangering safety of the national economy and currency stability",{{cite web |url=http://bistrita.citynews.ro/politica/usl-depus-plangere-penala-impotriva-lui-oltean-basescu-si-alti-13-pedelisti-vezi-ce-spune |title=USL a depus plângere penală împotriva lui Oltean, Băsescu și alți 13 pedeliști |work=CityNews.ro |date=20 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} given that Băsescu cataloged the events as a "coup d'état". In the following days, Crin Antonescu cut Băsescu's special phone line, after the Senate's Defence Committee found out that the Special Telecommunication Agency illegally deployed the secret phone line at Băsescu's office.{{cite news |url=http://www.nineoclock.ro/antonescu-cuts-basescu%E2%80%99s-special-phone-line-suspended-president-denounces-new-%E2%80%98coup%E2%80%99/ |title=Antonescu cuts Băsescu's special phone line, suspended president denounces new 'coup' |newspaper=Nine O'Clock |author =Rodica Pricop |date=22 July 2012}} Băsescu accused USL of dismantling all national security institutions and cataloged them as "a gang of traitors". The [[Romanian presidential impeachment referendum, 2012|presidential impeachment referendum]] took place on 29 July. On 21 August, the Constitutional Court decided that the referendum is invalid due to presence under 50%. However, 87.52% of those present in the referendum voted for Băsescu's impeachment.{{cite web |url=http://www.becreferendum2012.ro/DOCUMENTE%20BEC/Rezultate/Rezultate%20finale.pdf |title=Comunicat privind rezultatele referendumului național din data de 29 iulie 2012 pentru demiterea Președintelui României |work=Central Electoral Bureau |date=1 August 2012 |language=Romanian}} PDL boycotted the referendum,{{cite web |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/politic/pdl-boicoteaza-referendumul-alegatorii-sa-nu-participe-la-vot-pe-29-iulie-9899083 |title=PDL boicotează referendumul: Alegătorii să nu participe la vot pe 29 iulie |work=Mediafax |date=24 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} while the Hungarian Prime Minister [[Viktor Orbán]] exhorted ethnic Hungarians in Romania to stay away from the polls,{{cite web |url=http://www.politics.hu/20120730/romanian-pm-claims-outrage-over-hungarian-counterparts-comments-on-impeachment-referendum/ |title=Romanian PM claims "outrage" over Hungarian counterpart's comments on impeachment referendum |work=Politics.hu |date=30 July 2012}} fact that explains the low turnout in Hungarian majority counties of [[Harghita County|Harghita]] and [[Covasna County|Covasna]]. There were rumors regarding [[vote rigging]]. In October 2013, Deputy Prime Minister [[Liviu Dragnea]] and 74 others were accused of falsifying data to sway the vote's outcome.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-24437209 |title=Romania deputy PM Liviu Dragnea faces vote fraud charge |work=BBC News |date=7 October 2013}} On 22 April 2016, Liviu Dragnea was sentenced to two years [[probation]].{{cite web |url=http://www.digi24.ro/Stiri/Digi24/Actualitate/Justitie/Liviu+Dragnea+condamnat+la+doi+ani+de+inchisoare+cu+suspendare |title=Liviu Dragnea, condamnat la doi ani de închisoare cu suspendare |work=Digi24 |date=22 April 2016}} ==== Related protests ==== [[File:MRU proteste Victoria 6-7-12 03.jpg|thumb|[[Mihai Răzvan Ungureanu]] at a protest in Victory Square on 6 July]] {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | footer = Pro- ''(left)'' and anti-Băsescu ''(right)'' demonstrations in Bucharest | image1 = Discurs Băsescu 3, protest Piaţa Revoluţiei 26-7-12.jpg | width1 = 200 | image2 = Univ Sq Anti-Băsescu protests and factory fire 5-7-12 02.jpg | width2 = 173 }} The summer of 2012 in Romania was marked not only by political instability, but by civil unrest. In early July, on the background of plagiarism scandal, demonstrations took place in several locations in Bucharest. The demonstrations, entitled suggestively the "Protest of inverted commas" ({{lang-ro|Protestul ghilimelelor}}), were attended by hundreds of people, among them former Prime Minister Ungureanu, aiming Victor Ponta's resignation.{{cite web |url=http://www.romania-insider.com/protests-in-pta-universitatii-and-pta-victoriei-against-romanias-entire-political-scene/60195/ |title=Protests downtown Bucharest against Romania's entire political scene |work=Romania-Insider.com |author =Ioana Toader |date=5 July 2012}} In the pre-referendum period, several demonstrations in support of President Traian Băsescu took place throughout the country. In [[Arad, Romania|Arad]] and [[Timișoara]], clashes between pro- and anti-Băsescu demonstrators erupted, but were quickly dispersed by gendarmes. On 6 July, 2,000 people gathered at a rally in Bucharest to support President Băsescu. The rally was attended by prominent members of PDL and degenerated towards evening in altercations with anti-Băsescu demonstrators that infiltrated among supporters of the president.{{cite web |url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/actualitate/proteste-contra-basescu-in-piata-universitatii-cativa-manifestanti-s-au-luat-la-bataie.html |title=Proteste pro și contra Băsescu în Capitală. Câțiva manifestanți s-au luat la bătaie |work=Știrile Pro TV |date=6 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[File:Băsescu îi prezintă pe MRU, Cristian Preda & Adrian Papahagi, protest Piaţa Revoluţiei 26-7-12.jpg|thumb|left|[[Traian Băsescu]] speaking in his support at an anti-impeachment protest in Revolution Square, Bucharest]] Major political rallies were organized by USL in the most important cities in the country, within the campaign to dismiss the suspended president: [[Bucharest]] (50,000 participants, 26 July),{{cite news |url=http://adevarul.ro/news/bucuresti/fotogalerie-antonescu-mitingul-usl-romexpo-eu-nu-mai-cauta-politica-nu-vom-9-milioane-romani-curati-picioare-1_50be01eb7c42d5a663d1bffc/index.html# |title=Antonescu, la mitingul USL de la Romexpo: "Eu nu mai am ce căuta în politică dacă nu vom fi 9 milioane de români curați, în picioare" |newspaper=Adevărul |author =Cătălina Mihu |date=26 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Craiova]] (18,000 participants, 20 July),{{cite web |url=http://a1.ro/news/politic/miting-usl-la-craiova-18-000-de-oameni-cer-demiterea-lui-basescu-id131646.html |title=Miting USL la Craiova: 18.000 de oameni cer demiterea lui Băsescu! |work=Antena 1 |date=20 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Iași]] (15,000 participants, 22 July),{{cite news |url=http://www.evz.ro/crin-antonescu-si-victor-ponta-la-mitingul-usl-de-la-iasi-992966.html |title=Victor Ponta, la mitingul USL de la Iași: "Sunt mândru să fiu înjurat de Traian Băsescu" |newspaper=Evenimentul Zilei |author =Carmen Vintilă |date=1 August 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Oradea]] (8,000 participants, 24 July),{{cite web |url=http://www.antena3.ro/romania/aproximativ-8-000-de-persoane-participa-la-mitingul-usl-de-la-oradea-da-la-referendum-177012.html |title=Aproximativ 8.000 de persoane participă la mitingul USL de la Oradea: "DA la referendum" |work=Antena 3 |date=24 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Pitești]] (7,000 participants, 25 July),{{cite news |url=http://adevarul.ro/locale/alexandria/cateva-mii-oameni-mitinguri-arges-teleorman-demiterea-traian-basescu-1_50ae24a17c42d5a66399f913/index.html |title=Câteva mii de oameni, la mitinguri în Argeș și Teleorman pentru demiterea lui Traian Băsescu |newspaper=Adevărul |date=26 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Brașov]] (5,000 participants, 17 July),{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-politic-12819872-miting-usl-brasov-pentru-demiterea-lui-traian-basescu-peste-5-000-persoane-participa-manifestatie.htm |title=Miting USL la Brașov, pentru demiterea lui Traian Băsescu: Peste 5.000 de persoane participă la manifestație |work=HotNews.ro |author =R.M. |date=17 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Alexandria, Romania|Alexandria]] (1,500 participants, 25 July) and [[Râmnicu Vâlcea]] (700 participants, 27 July). On the other side, large pro-Băsescu meetings were organized in several Romanian cities, at different dates, to avoid potential conflicts between demonstrators: [[Bucharest]] (15,000 participants),{{cite news |url=http://www.gandul.info/politica/miting-pro-basescu-15-000-de-pedelisti-asteptati-in-piata-revolutiei-9904665 |title=Miting Pro Bǎsescu. 15.000 de pedeliști așteptați în Piața Revoluției |newspaper=Gândul |date=26 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Iași]] (10,000 participants),{{cite news |url=http://www.libertatea.ro/detalii/articol/taie-miting-iasi-pro-basescu-404961.html |title=Bǎtaie la mitingul pro-Băsescu, organizat la Iași |newspaper=Libertatea |date=21 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Cluj-Napoca]] (10,000 participants),{{cite news |url=http://www.zf.ro/politica/circa-10-000-de-participanti-la-mitingul-pro-basescu-de-la-cluj-9861861 |title=Circa 10.000 de participanți la mitingul pro-Băsescu de la Cluj |newspaper=Ziarul Financiar |author1=Vasile Măgrădean |author2=Andreea Tobias |date=14 July 2012 |language=Romanian}} [[Slatina, Romania|Slatina]] (100 participants). Invalidation of the referendum infuriated Băsescu's opposers that gathered in their thousands in front of the [[National Theatre Bucharest|Bucharest National Theatre]]. Protesters shouted messages against CCR decision to invalidate the referendum and asked Traian Băsescu to resign. Likewise, many people have come up with anti-US placards, considering that Băsescu was reinstated at Americans desire.{{cite web |url=http://www.ziare.com/stiri/proteste/proteste-pro-si-contra-basescu-in-pietele-din-bucuresti-dupa-decizia-ccr-1185549 |title=Proteste anti-Băsescu și anti-SUA la Universitate – Decizia CCR a scos sute de oameni în stradă |work=Ziare.com |author =Alexandra Șandru |date=22 August 2012 |language=Romanian}} Towards evening things got out of control, people breached fences and entered on the carriageway, blocking traffic. Next day, the Gendarmerie fined or queried 106 people for disturbing public peace and destruction of public domain.{{cite news |url=http://jurnalul.ro/stiri/observator/cadorisiti-cu-dosare-penale-pentru-ca-au-protestat-impotriva-lui-traian-basescu-621930.html |title=Cadorisiți cu dosare penale pentru că au protestat împotriva lui Traian Băsescu |newspaper=Jurnalul Național |date=24 August 2012 |language=Romanian}} === 2013 social protests === Worsening working conditions, mass layoffs and poor payroll have taken to the streets thousands of employees even in the early days of 2013. Probably the most dramatic and publicized case is [[Oltchim S.A.|Oltchim Râmnicu Vâlcea]], one of the largest chemical companies in Romania. The company recorded losses of €90.3 million in the fourth quarter of 2011, thus ending the year with a negative result of 270 million lei.{{cite news |url=http://www.cotidianul.ro/statul-a-pierdut-135-mil-euro-datoria-oltchim-a-fost-convertita-in-actiuni-175398/ |title=Statul a pierdut 135 mil. euro: Datoria Oltchim a fost convertită în acțiuni |newspaper=Cotidianul |author =Dan Zăvăleanu |date=8 March 2012 |language=Romanian}}{{cite news |url=http://media.hotnews.ro/media_server1/document-2013-03-13-14407961-0-oltchim-raport-privind-cauzele-care-generat-starea-insolventa.pdf |title=Raport privind cauzele și împrejurările care au dus la apariția stării de insolvență a debitoarei S.C. Oltchim S.A. |newspaper=HotNews.ro |date=13 March 2013 |language=Romanian}} The company's leadership was forced to reduce expenses and liabilities, even without announcing employees. The deplorable situation of the company triggered mass unrest, also fueled by several failed attempts to privatize the plant. Protests took place throughout the year, one of the largest being organized on 28 March, when nearly 1,500 employees refused to start work and blocked the traffic on national road DN64.{{cite news |url=http://www.romanialibera.ro/economie/companii/protestele-de-la-oltchim-iau-amploare--angajatii-au-blocat-din-nou-dn-64--un-protestatar--lovit-de-o-masina-297449 |title=Protestele de la Oltchim iau Amploare. Angajații au blocat din nou DN 64. Un protestatar, lovit de o mașină |newspaper=România Liberă |date=28 March 2013 |language=Romanian}} The unrest escalated with the storming of company's headquarters on 4 July, while in the subsequent months, some employees launched a [[hunger strike]].{{cite news |url=http://adevarul.ro/locale/ramnicu-valcea/a-treia-zi-greva-foamei-oltchim-doi-protestatari-avut-nevoie-ingrijiri-medicale-1_529ed82ec7b855ff567002c6/index.html |title=A treia zi de greva foamei la Oltchim: doi protestatari au avut nevoie de îngrijiri medicale |newspaper=Adevărul |author =Irina Rîpan |date=4 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} ==== CFR crisis ==== The deplorable situation of the [[Romanian Railways|national railway company]] took to the streets thousands of employees under the threat of job loss or salary reduction.{{cite web |url=http://www.realitatea.net/ceferistii-protesteaza-la-ministerul-transporturilor_1233560.html |title=2.500 de ceferiști au protestat la Guvern și la Ministerul Transporturilor |work=Realitatea.net |date=26 July 2013 |language=Romanian}} In 2013 and 2014, the company was shaken by two major strikes. On 16 January 2013, thousands of employees triggered a spontaneous strike,{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-16/romania-railway-workers-start-unplanned-strike-mediafax.html |title=Romania Railway Workers Start Unplanned Strike: Mediafax |work=Bloomberg |author =Andra Timu |date=16 January 2013}} 138 trains being blocked for several hours in major railway stations in the country, including [[Bucharest]], [[Craiova]], [[Cluj-Napoca]], [[Iași]], [[Galați]] and [[Constanța]].{{cite web |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/greva-spontana-la-cfr-calatori-angajatii-nu-si-au-primit-salariile-pe-decembrie-89-de-trenuri-nu-au-plecat-din-statii-lider-sindical-greva-spontana-din-cfr-infrastructura-si-cfr-calatori-se-incheie-la-ora-9-00-10474028 |title=Grevă Spontană la CFR Călători. Angajații nu și-au primit salariile pe decembrie. 138 de trenuri, afectate. Fenechiu: Cei vinovați vor plăti |work=Mediafax |author =Ioana Câmpean |date=16 January 2013 |language=Romanian}} The Minister of Transport [[Relu Fenechiu]] said that he will make an analysis and those responsible will pay. A larger strike took place on 23 April 2014, when, for two hours, rail traffic was paralyzed in major train stations in the country. According to syndicalists, the protest took place after failed negotiations on a new collective agreement.{{cite news |url=http://www.evz.ro/greva-la-cfr-niciun-tren-nu-va-circula-miercuri-intre-700-si-900-.html |title=Greva de la CFR. Sindicaliștii negociază, dar nu exclud alte proteste. Miza: majorări salariale și transport feroviar gratuit |newspaper=Evenimentul Zilei |author1=Alexandra Ciliac |author2=Ana-Maria Adamoae |author3=Georgeta Petrovici |author4=Silvana Chiujdea |date=23 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} About 400 [[passenger train]]s and 200 [[freight train]]s stood in the stations or on route.{{cite news |url=http://www.gandul.info/stiri/greva-la-cfr-calator-pentru-gandul-am-ajuns-si-noi-o-data-cu-5-minute-mai-devreme-in-statie-si-au-facut-greva-12506514 |title=Grevǎ la CFR. Călător, pentru Gândul: "Am ajuns și noi o dată cu 5 minute mai devreme în stație și au făcut grevă" |newspaper=Gândul |date=23 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} ==== Protests of teachers and students ==== Protests and strikes were launched by teachers and students throughout the year, centered mainly on Ponta's poor policies regarding education. They claim that the education system is underfunded and require allocation of at least 6% of GDP to education. High school students also protested for bad settlement of commuting subscriptions. On 21 May, over 2,000 students in [[Covasna County]] went on Japanese strike, inasmuch as the Ministry of Education hasn't settled, since October 2012, money for commuting subscriptions.{{cite news |url=http://www.curierulnational.ro/Actualitate/2013-05-21/2.000+de+elevi+din+Covasna,+in+greva+japoneza+pentru+ca+nu+le-au+fost+decontate+abonamentele+pentru+naveta&hl=Auto&tip=toate |title=2.000 de elevi din Covasna, în grevă japoneză pentru că nu le-au fost decontate abonamentele pentru navetă |newspaper=Curierul Național |date=21 May 2013 |language=Romanian}} Those 2,000 students that went on Japanese strike, wearing white banderoles on arm, are from 15 high schools in the cities of [[Sfântu Gheorghe]], [[Târgu Secuiesc]], [[Covasna]] and [[Baraolt]]. Furthermore, students in Covasna organized a protest meeting. The Ministry of Education has accumulated, from October to March, a debt of more than 1.6 million lei for settlement of students commuting subscriptions in Covasna County.{{cite web |url=http://www.amosnews.ro/2000-de-elevi-din-covasna-greva-2013-05-21 |title=2.000 de elevi din Covasna, în grevă |work=Amos News |date=21 May 2013 |language=Romanian}} Likewise, around 150 students from high schools throughout the [[Mureș County]] went on indefinitely Japanese strike, in solidarity with the colleagues which were not settled money for commuting subscriptions.{{cite news |url=http://adevarul.ro/locale/targu-mures/mures-elevi-greva-japoneza-decont-naveta-covasna-1_51a3521bc7b855ff562f1203/index.html |title=150 de elevi din Mureș sunt în grevă japoneză, din cauza banilor de navetă nedecontați. Elevii din Covasna vor ieși în stradă joi |newspaper=Adevărul |date=27 May 2013 |language=Romanian}} The same measure of protest was adopted by hundreds of students in [[Constanța County]], according to that were violated the rights under the Education Act through art. 84 (3).{{cite web |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/constanta-elevii-navetisti-au-intrat-in-greva-japoneza-10905561 |title=Constanța: Elevii navetiști au intrat în grevă japoneză |work=Mediafax |author =Cosmin Vaideanu |date=28 May 2013 |language=Romanian}} In [[Cluj County]], Ministry of Education didn't settle any money for seven months.{{cite web |url=http://www.ziare.com/stiri/greva-invatamant/criza-elevilor-navetisti-ministerul-educatiei-are-datorii-de-milioane-de-lei-la-cluj-1238039 |title=Criza elevilor navetiști: Ministerul Educației are datorii de milioane de lei la Cluj |work=Ziare.com |date=29 May 2013 |language=Romanian}} Accumulated debts amount to more than 3.5 million lei, 3,100 commuter students being affected by this situation.{{cite web |url=http://www.realitatea.net/ministerul-educatiei-datorii-de-3-5-milioane-de-lei-catre-elevii-din-cluj_1192122.html |title=Ministerul Educației, datorii de 3,5 milioane de lei către elevii din Cluj |work=Realitatea.net |date=29 May 2013 |language=Romanian}} On 13 November, thousands of students from 11 universities in [[Bucharest]], [[Timișoara]], [[Cluj-Napoca]], [[Iași]], [[Constanța]], [[Galați]], [[Baia Mare]], [[Sibiu]], [[Suceava]], [[Oradea]] and [[Alba Iulia]] took to the streets to protest the underfunding of the education system.{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-16016588-studentii-din-bucuresti-din-principalele-centre-universitare-ale-tarii-ies-strada-pentru-protesta-impotriva-subfinantarii-din-educatie-mitingul-din-capitala-incepe-ora-14-00-piata-universitatii-restri.htm |title=Studenții protestează față de "subfinanțarea" din educație. Protestatarii au pornit dinspre Piața Victoriei către sediul Ministerului Educației |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author1=A. Neagu |author2=V. Cozmei |author3=R. Pantazi |date=13 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} In solidarity with the students, pupils from dozens of schools and high schools went on Japanese strike. Students chanted slogans against the Government and demanded allocation of 6% of GDP for education: „We want a school for all, not a Government of mobsters”, „Finance the education or leave the Government”.{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/protest-studentii-ies-in-strada-si-cer-6prc-pentru-educatie-elevii-in-greva-japoneza_1315355.html |title=Studenții, în stradă, pentru Educație și împotriva Guvernului. Drum Blocat, în Capitală |newspaper=Realitatea.net |date=13 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} According to the Romanian press, the event is one of the largest [[student movement]]s in recent years.{{cite news |url=http://stiri.tvr.ro/protest-de-amploare-al-studentilor-mii-de-tineri-din-11-centre-universitare-ies-in-strada_37105.html |title=Protest de amploare al studenților. Mii de tineri din 11 centre universitare ies în stradă |newspaper=Știrile TVR |date=13 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} Teachers' wages is a problem wherewith the education system confronts. In Romania, a teacher is paid 9.3 lei net (2.09 euros) per hour, compared to other European countries, where wages are up to 40 times higher.{{cite news |url=http://www.romanialibera.ro/societate/educatie/comparatie-%C5%9Eocanta-intre-salariile-profesorilor-din-europa--dascalii-din-romania--umili%C5%A2i-306603 |title=Comparație Șocantă între salariile profesorilor din Europa. Dascălii din România, Umiliți |newspaper=România Liberă |author =Raluca Filipescu |date=4 July 2013 |language=Romanian}} In May 2015, starting from [[Timișoara]], [[Galați]] and [[Constanța]], students have occupied university amphitheatres, protesting "the disaster in academic environment and the lack of respect with which students were treated in decisions regarding the higher education system".{{cite web |url=http://www.gandul.info/stiri/studentii-din-romania-au-inceput-miscarea-occupy-universitatile-sunt-pentru-studenti-care-sunt-revendicarile-tinerilor-care-dorm-in-amfiteatre-14218840 |title=Studenții din România au început mișcarea Occupy: "Universitățile sunt pentru studenți". Care sunt revendicările tinerilor care dorm în amfiteatre |work=Gândul |last=Ofițeru |first=Andreea |date=6 May 2015 |language=Romanian}} Triggered by the [[National Alliance of Student Organizations in Romania]],{{cite web |url=http://adevarul.ro/educatie/universitar/studentii-s-au-baricadat-mai-multe-universitati-tara-protesteaza-fata-sistemul-invatamant-1_5548e930cfbe376e35e0a537/index.html |title=Studenții s-au baricadat în mai multe universități din țară. Protestează față de sistemul de învățământ |work=Adevărul |last=Garaiman |first=Roxana |date=5 May 2015 |language=Romanian}} After failed negotiations with the Minister of Education Sorin Cîmpeanu, protests spread to other universities in [[Bucharest]], [[Iași]], [[Cluj-Napoca]], [[Reșița]], [[Oradea]] and [[Suceava]].{{cite web |url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/social/mobilizare-a-studentilor-din-mai-multe-orase-tinerii-vor-un-invatamant-mai-bun-si-sunt-dispusi-sa-faca-greva-foamei.html |title=Proteste în universitățile din țară. Discuțiile dintre studenți și ministrul Educației nu au dus la niciun rezultat |work=Știrile Pro TV |date=7 May 2015 |language=Romanian}} Students are also dissatisfied with university tuition fees, invoking a university dropout rate of 40%.{{cite web |url=http://www.ziare.com/scoala/universitati/protest-in-universitatile-din-tara-studentii-au-ocupat-amfiteatrele-ce-revendicari-au-1361716 |title=Protest în universitățile din țară: Studenții au ocupat amfiteatrele – ce revendicări au |work=Ziare.com |date=5 May 2015 |language=Romanian}} The events are known in Romanian press as Occupy University.{{cite web |url=http://stiri.tvr.ro/exclusiv--occupy-university-la-bucuresti--studentii-denunta-subfinantarea-invatamantului_60012.html |title="Occupy University" la București. Studenții denunţă subfinanțarea învățământului |work=Știrile TVR |date=6 May 2015 |language=Romanian}} ==== Doctors' strike ==== [[File:Marşul Tăcerii.jpg|thumb|March of Silence, 2 November]] Situation in hospitals, poor payroll and lack of staff pushed the doctors to launch an ample program of protests aimed to alarm the minister [[Eugen Nicolăescu]] over collapse of Romanian health system. In September were held for two weeks picketings in front of the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Finance.{{cite news |url=http://www.capital.ro/au-inceput-protestele-medicilor-din-toata-tara-186674.html |title=Au început protestele medicilor: pentru ce au ieșit în stradă |newspaper=Capital |author =Nicoleta Bănilă |date=18 September 2013 |language=Romanian}} The protests are the largest since 1998{{cite web |url=http://www.digi24.ro/Stiri/Digi24/Actualitate/Sanatate/Medicii+si+asistentii+ies+in+strada+Protestul+halatelor+albe |title=Medicii și asistenții au ieșit în stradă. Protestul halatelor albe, cel mai amplu din ultimii 15 ani |work=Digi24 |date=18 September 2013 |language=Romanian}} and are known in local media as "Protest of white robes" ({{lang-ro|Protestul halatelor albe}}). On 2 November, nearly 7,000 doctors, nurses and dentists marched on [[Calea Victoriei|Victory Avenue]], towards the [[Palace of the Parliament]]. The manifestation, called "March of Silence" ({{lang-ro|Marșul Tăcerii}}),{{cite web |url=http://stiri.tvr.ro/marsul-tacerii-cadrele-medicale-protesteaza-sambata-in-capitala_36690.html |title="Marșul Tăcerii". Cadrele medicale protestează, sâmbătă, în Capitală |work=Știrile TVR |date=1 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} was joined by medical staff across the country. Demonstrators leaned against the wall of the Palace of the Parliament a cross and nearly 20 wreaths, thus suggesting the "death of health" in Romania.{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.com/2013/11/02/romania-thousands-of-doctors-and-nurses-march-in-bucharest-for-better-health-/ |title=Romania: Thousands of doctors and nurses march in Bucharest for better health service |newspaper=Euronews |date=2 November 2013}} After three rounds of failed negotiations with the Minister of Health, on 25 November, more than 130,000 health professionals{{cite news |url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/actualitate/medicii-intra-in-greva-de-avertisment-luni-dimineata-vor-fi-asigurate-doar-urgentele-medicale.html |title=Angajații din sănătate au fost în Grevǎ de avertisment. Care sunt revendicările |newspaper=Știrile Pro TV |date=25 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} from across the country have triggered a warning [[strike action|strike]] between 8 and 10 o'clock.{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-16067000-greva-avertisment-sanatate-intre-orele-8-00-10-00.htm |title=Cadrele medicale sunt în grevă de avertisment până la ora 10.00. Marius Sepi (Sanitas): Peste 100.000 de angajați participă la protest |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author =Carla Dinu |date=25 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} During this time, polyclinics were closed, and hospitals operated only in medical emergencies.{{cite news |url=http://www.gandul.info/stiri/greva-de-avertisment-in-sanatate-intre-8-si-10-medicii-vor-salarii-mai-mari-joi-ar-putea-fi-greva-generala-11718835 |title=Grevǎ de avertisment în sănătate, între 8 și 10. Medicii vor salarii mai mari. Joi ar putea fi Grevǎ Generalǎ |newspaper=Gândul |author =Laura Mitran |date=25 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} Marius Sepi, first vice-president of Sanitas Federation, stated that the strike was affected by some hospital managers that threatened the protesters.{{cite news |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/angajatii-din-sistemul-sanitar-in-greva-de-avertisment-protestatarii-reclama-ca-au-salarii-mici-si-cer-demisia-ministrului-sanatatii-11718852 |title=Grevǎ de Avertisment în Sănătate. Protestatarii cer demisia ministrului Sănătății. Președintele Sanitas: Dacă greva va fi declarată ilegală, angajații vor cere să primească liberele restante |newspaper=Mediafax |date=25 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} Even the Minister of Health, Eugen Nicolăescu, considered the strike illegal and said he didn't know if it's possible to increase wages.{{cite news |url=http://www.romanialibera.ro/stil-de-viata/sanatate/video-nicolaescu-greva-din-sistemul-sanitar-ilegala-318396.html |title=Nicolăescu: Greva din sistemul sanitar, ilegală |newspaper=România Liberă |date=20 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} Despite major changes on Romanian political scene in early 2014, the new health minister could not cope with the demands of health professionals. In this regard, doctors picketed between 23 June and 4 July the headquarters of Ministry of Health, Ministry of Labour and Ministry of Public Finance.{{cite news |url=http://adevarul.ro/news/societate/un-nou-val-proteste-sanatate-personalul-medical-ameninta-greva-1_53a7d2830d133766a8d1bdda/index.html |title=Un nou val de proteste în sistemul sanitar. Posturile vacante din spitalele publice vor fi scoase la concurs |newspaper=Adevărul |author =Claudia Spridon |date=23 June 2014 |language=Romanian}} ==== Duty of 7 cents ==== There was a rough dispute between President Băsescu and Premier Ponta on fuel price rise by 7 cents, measure adopted since 1 April 2014. The head of state asked Victor Ponta to waive the fee he deems an unnecessary and discriminatory tax burden. Likewise, Traian Băsescu is convinced that the measure will lead to tax evasion.{{cite web |url=http://www.digi24.ro/Stiri/Digi24/Economie/Stiri/Scumpiri+carburanti+1+aprilie+benzinarii+cozi+comunism+gaze |title=Carburanți supraaccizați și scumpiri în lanț de la 1 aprilie. Benzinăriile au fost luate cu asalt |work=Digi24 |date=31 March 2014 |language=Romanian}} The measure was also criticized by opposition. Thus, on 15 March, between 8,000 and 10,000 people,{{cite news |url=http://www.b1.ro/stiri/eveniment/protest-in-bucure-ti-fa-a-de-acciza-pe-carburan-i-organizat-de-partidul-mi-carea-populara-78128.html |title=Protest în București față de acciza pe carburanți, organizat de Partidul Mișcarea Populară |newspaper=B1.ro |date=15 March 2014 |language=Romanian}} members or supporters of the [[People's Movement Party]], protested in [[Bucharest]]'s George Enescu Square against Ponta's poor economic policies and wave of taxes that will be introduced once with 1 April.{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/acciza-la-carburanti-i-a-scos-in-strada-mii-de-oameni-la-mitingul-pmp_1399894.html |title=Acciza la carburanți i-a scos în stradă: Mii de Oameni, la mitingul PMP |newspaper=Realitatea.net |date=15 March 2014 |language=Romanian}} Romania figures among the countries with the most expensive gasoline in the world, at $7.38 per gallon (€1.41 per litre).{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/visual-data/best-and-worst/highest-gas-prices-countries |title=Highest Gas Prices: Countries |work=Bloomberg |date=29 April 2014}} Protests related to fuel overtaxing also took place a few months before the implementation of this measure. On 9 December 2013, over 86,000 lorry drivers across the country went on strike and blocked for several hours the traffic on ring roads of major cities.{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-16164124-transportatorii-rutieri-marfuri-intrat-greva.htm |title=Transportatorii rutieri de mărfuri au intrat în grevă. În mai multe județe au blocat șoselele de centură |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author =Carla Dinu |date=9 December 2013 |language=Romanian}}{{cite news |url=http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/greva-in-transporturi-incepand-de-maine-1071443.html |title=Greva Transportatorilor: 86.000 de camioane blochează drumurile! Magazinele se tem că rămân fără produse proaspete |newspaper=Evenimentul Zilei |author =Raluca Florescu |date=9 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} === Protests against the Roșia Montană Project === {{Main|2013 Romanian protests against the Roșia Montană Project}} [[File:Universitatea Bucuresti IMG 6613.JPG|thumb|A [[sit-in]] in [[University Square, Bucharest|University Square]], Bucharest]] The [[Roșia Montană Project]], a mining project aimed to bring to the surface 350 tonnes of gold and 1,500 tonnes of silver,{{cite web |url=http://thejournalist.ie/comment/europes-ecological-time-bomb-rosia-montana-gold-mine-hills-romania/ |title=Europe's Ecological Time Bomb: Roșia Montană Gold Mine in the Hills of Romania |work=The Journalist |author =Randy Gener |date=25 September 2013}} met a significant resistance from environmental groups in Romania and neighbouring countries. Among the dissatisfactions of environmentalists are the pollution by cyanidation and the extremely low percentage of which Romania will benefit from this exploitation.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-23865805 |title=Romania gold project at Roșia Montană back on track |work=BBC News |date=28 August 2013}} A concern was the fact that the legislation would give the Roșia Montană Gold Corporation the right to give compulsory purchase orders to the residents of [[Roșia Montană]] who refused to sell their houses and lands.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/sep/04/protest-rosia-montana-gold-mine-protest |title=Protests continue in Bucharest against gold mine plan in Roșia Montană |newspaper=The Guardian |author =Grace Wong |date=4 September 2013}} The draft law also sets time limits for the state authorities to grant all permits, regardless of potential infringements of national legislation or of court rulings.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/sep/17/romanians-mobilise-gold-mine |title=Romanians mobilise in protest against gold mine plans |newspaper=The Guardian |author =Claudia Ciobanu |date=17 September 2013}} [[File:Foisorul de foc IMG 7273.JPG|thumb|left|Protesters blocking traffic near [[Foișorul de Foc]], [[Bucharest]]]] The wave of protests started on 1 September 2013 with a national mobilization and continued until late-December. The protests attracted up to 200,000 demonstrators in 50 Romanian cities and 30 cities in Romanian diaspora.{{cite web |url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-1051083 |title=Romania on fire: The Romanian Autumn expands |work=CNN iReport |author =Raluca Besliu |date=21 October 2013}} Largest demonstrations were organized in [[Bucharest]] (20,000 people), [[Cluj-Napoca]] (10,000 people),{{cite web |url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-1039393 |title=Over 10,000 people march in Cluj to protest against the Roșia Montană project |work=CNN iReport |author =Laura Mureșan |date=22 September 2013}} [[Câmpeni]] (4,000 people),{{cite news |url=http://www.cotidianul.ro/marea-adunare-a-motilor-impotriva-proiectului-minier-de-la-rosia-montana-224786/ |title=Marea adunare a moților împotriva proiectului minier de la Roșia Montană |newspaper=Cotidianul |author =Sorin Popa |date=19 October 2013 |language=Romanian}} [[Iași]] (1,500 people) and [[Brașov]] (900 people).{{cite web |url=http://rt.com/news/cyanide-gold-romania-protest-585/ |title=Cyanide pollution fears: Thousands of Romanians protest 'biggest in Europe' gold mine |work=RT |date=8 September 2013}} In [[Bucharest]], [[Timișoara]] and [[Iași]], protesters created "[[tent city|tent cities]]", paralyzing traffic on major arteries of circulation. The protests, dubbed by international media the "Romanian Autumn",{{cite web |url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-1032434 |title='The Arab Spring, the Turkish Summer, The Romanian Autumn': Romanian protests as a model of peaceful demonstration |work=CNN iReport |author =Raluca Besliu |date=6 September 2013}} have taken many forms: [[human chain]]s around the [[Palace of the Parliament]], [[flash mob]]s, [[roadblock]]s and scuffles with police. Although the protests were mainly peaceful, there were reports of serious incidents. On 13 September, Minister of Culture [[Daniel Barbu]] was attacked with tomatoes in [[Cluj-Napoca]]. In November, protesters in [[Bucharest]], [[Brașov]] and [[Cluj-Napoca]] were aggressed and sprayed with irritant substances by gendarmes, in the capital 62 people being fined for blocking traffic.{{cite news |url=http://adevarul.ro/news/eveniment/protest-rosia-montana-1_5289f12fc7b855ff560bd0bf/index.html |title=62 de persoane au fost amendate la protestul față de proiectul minier "Roșia Montană" de duminică după ce au blocat circulația |newspaper=Adevărul |author =Mihai Stoica |date=18 November 2013 |language=Romanian}} Likewise, on 9 December, about 50 [[Greenpeace]] activists from 10 countries who were protesting in the courtyard of the Parliament building, were seized by gendarmes and led to the police stations. Protesters also accused the poor coverage of the protests by Romanian media. There were also protests in support of the mining project. Organized only in the exploitation area, the largest protest attracted up to 5,000 locals and 33 miners blocked underground, who were fighting for the jobs promised by Roșia Montană Gold Corporation, inasmuch as the unemployment rate in the area is very high. In an attempt to defuse the tense situation of Roșia Montană, Prime Minister Victor Ponta descended into the underground to discuss with miners.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/15/us-romania-goldmine-protest-idUSBRE98E0FJ20130915 |title=Romanian gold miners end underground protest after PM's visit |work=Reuters |author =Radu Marinaș |date=15 September 2013}} However, during massive protests against Roșia Montană Project, Ponta – main target of protests – didn't conduct any conversation with the representatives of the protesters. === Resistance against shale gas === {{Main|2012–14 Romanian protests against shale gas}} === "Black Tuesday" and subsequent protests === The [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Chamber of Deputies]] passed, on 10 December 2013, a draft law containing multiple amendments to the [[Penal Code of Romania|Penal Code]], which would grant "super-immunity" to MPs and the president, as they would be taken out of the "public servant" category stipulated in the Code.{{cite news |url=http://euobserver.com/justice/122424 |title=Romanian MPs decriminalise political corruption |newspaper=EUobserver |author =Valentina Pop |date=11 December 2013}} Moreover, the amendments would protect politicians from the investigation of bodies of anti-corruption struggle ([[National Anticorruption Directorate]], National Integrity Agency) and would remove the [[conflict of interest]] from the list of misdemeanors.{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2013/12/legally-corrupt-romanian-politicians-chase-super-immunity-2013123183238113962.html |title=Legally corrupt: Romanian politicians chase 'super-immunity' |newspaper=Aljazeera |author =Raluca Besliu |date=18 January 2014}} After the Romanian Parliament passed the amendments, media outlets marked the day as the "Black Tuesday" of Romanian democracy.{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/adam-cernea-clark/romania-in-crisis-police-_b_4446185.html |title=Romania in Crisis: Police Violence, Political Immunity, and Environmental Discontents |newspaper=The Huffington Post |author =Adam Cernea Clark |date=16 December 2013}} On 14 December, nearly 1,500 people{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-politic-16205326-miscarea-populara-organizeaza-miting-impotriva-usl-sambata-ora-12-00-piata-victoriei.htm |title=Circa 1.500 de manifestanți la protestul organizat de Mișcarea Populară în fața Guvernului, dupa asaltul majorității parlamentare asupra justiției, din "marțea neagră". Revendicările: Demisia Executivului, a Parlamentului și alegeri anticipate |newspaper=HotNews.ro |date=14 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} attended a meeting organized by [[People's Movement Party]], in sign of protest against new Penal Code.{{cite news |url=http://www.romanialibera.ro/actualitate/politica/update-miting-in-piata-victoriei-miscarea-populara-cheama-la-protest-impotriva-abuzurilor-usl-320559.html |title=Miting în Piața Victoriei. Mișcarea Populară cheamă la protest împotriva "abuzurilor USL" |newspaper=România Liberă |date=14 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} The next day, a similar protest took place in Bucharest and was attended by more than 2,000 people. Unlike the previous, this was more violent.{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-16213496-live-text-protest-impotriva-puslamalelor-din-parlament-piata-universitatii-din-capitala.htm |title=Protest cu incidente violente în Capitală. Jandarmii au folosit gaze lacrimogene pentru a dispersa manifestanții din fața Guvernului, unde s-a cerut demisia premierului Ponta |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author1=V. Cozmei |author2=V. Marin |date=15 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} A large number of police forces were deployed on the spot. They formed cordons to prevent protesters moving towards the Government headquarters. Angry crowd broke the cordons, and gendarmes used tear gas to avoid blocking traffic. After the altercations, four protesters were seized by gendarmes and taken to the police station.{{cite news |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/peste-200-de-persoane-protesteaza-la-universitate-fata-de-modificarile-aduse-codului-penal-live-text-11774056 |title=Protest În Capitalǎ față de modificările aduse Codului Penal. Patru manifestanți au fost ridicați de jandarmi, unul ajungând la spital |newspaper=Mediafax |author =Cătălin Lupășteanu |date=15 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} They were questioned and fined for disturbing public peace and order. One of the protesters was transported to the [[Floreasca Hospital]] with a wound to the head.{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/proteste-la-universitate-contra-parlamentului-proiectului-rosia-montana-si-a-gazelor-de-sist_1340411.html#ixzz2ndFuc6YU%20Follow%20us:%20@realitatea%20on%20Twitter |title=Proteste la Universitate și Guvern: "Jos Ponta!, Jos Bǎsescu!" Jandarmii au folosit gaze lacrimogene |newspaper=Realitatea.net |date=15 December 2013 |language=Romanian}}{{cite news |url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatches/globalpost-blogs/rights/protests-bucharest-rage-time-more-political |title=Anti-corruption protests in Bucharest take off as Romanians get political |newspaper=GlobalPost |author =Meredith Turk |date=17 December 2013}} On 21 December, more than 5,000 people attended a protest in Bucharest against all political classes and new Penal Code. The protest was held under the slogan ''21–22 we want the democracy back'' ({{lang-ro|21–22 vrem democrația înapoi}}).{{cite news |url=http://ro.stiri.yahoo.com/quot-21-22-vrem-democra%C5%A3ia-%C3%AEnapoi-quot-protest-132900665.html |title="21–22 vrem democrația înapoi" – Protest în Piața Universității |newspaper=Yahoo! News România |date=21 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} Mobilized on [[social network]]s, protesters demanded the resignation of Prime Minister Victor Ponta and President Traian Băsescu, but also the dissolution of Parliament. Throughout the protest, demonstrators lit candles in memory of victims of the [[Romanian Revolution|1989 Revolution]]. There were deployed hundreds of gendarmes, equipped for intervention, with batons and tear gas guns, vans and water cannons.{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-16255729-sambata-nou-miting-bucuresti-impotriva-modificarii-codului-penal-anuntat-prezenta-circa-900-persoane.htm |title=Un nou miting în Capitală, desfășurat fără incidente majore. Îmbrânceli cu jandarmii după ce un protestatar s-a urcat pe o mașină a Jandarmeriei |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author1=C. Ivanov |author2=C. Ionel |date=21 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} Protesters threw stones and bottles at vehicles of the Gendarmerie and accused the gendarmes of defending thievery. ==== Reactions ==== ===== Domestic ===== Amendments to the Penal Code were strongly contested by President [[Traian Băsescu]], who said that he will return to the Parliament the law through which the president and MPs are removed from the category of civil servants. The Head of State said that the amendments to the Penal Code adopted by the Chamber are "dramatic" and "tear down ten years of work and activity of anticorruption institutions" such as [[National Anticorruption Directorate]] (DNA) or National Integrity Agency (ANI).{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/basescu-modificarile-la-codul-penal-dramatice-darama-10-ani-de-munca-a-institutiilor-anticoruptie_1336819.html |title=Băsescu: Modificările la Codul penal, dramatice, dărămă 10 ani de muncă a instituțiilor anticorupție |newspaper=Realitatea.net |date=10 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} The President mentioned in a TV show about the [[dissolution of Parliament]], invoking the breach of the [[Copenhagen criteria]] through these amendments to the Penal Code.{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-politic-16189858-traian-basescu-invitat-adevarul-live-despre-modificarea-codului-penal-invitatie-furt-fara-teama-consecintele-legii.htm |title=Traian Băsescu vorbește despre dizolvarea Parlamentului, în cazul în care se mențin modificările aduse Codului penal: Am văzut reacția CE și a aliaților noștri, cu aceste modificări am ieși din criteriile de la Copenhaga, ceea ce ar fi extrem de grav. Pentru așa ceva un Parlament ar trebui dizolvat. Sancțiunile ar porni imediat, ar fi o situație dramatică, am fi în afara UE |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author =Alina Neagu |date=12 December 2013 |language=Romanian}}{{cite news |url=http://jurnalul.ro/stiri/politica/basescu-respinge-modificarile-la-codul-penal-aprobate-in-parlament-aceste-modificari-inseamna-10-ani-de-regres-657064.html |title=Băsescu respinge modificările la Codul Penal aprobate în Parlament: Aceste modificări înseamnă 10 ani de regres |newspaper=Jurnalul Național |date=10 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} The National Anticorruption Directorate showed that, following the changes to the Penal Code, lawmakers indicted for corruption or similar to that misdemeanor might be acquitted, and those detained through final sentence might be set free.{{cite news |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/politic/dna-despre-noile-modificari-aduse-codului-penal-parlamentarii-judecati-pentru-coruptie-ar-putea-fi-achitati-cei-condamnati-pusi-in-libertate-11754206 |title=DNA, despre noile modificări aduse Codului penal: Parlamentarii judecați pentru corupţie ar putea fi achitați. Cei condamnați, puși în libertate |newspaper=Mediafax |date=10 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} President of the National Integrity Agency, Horia Georgescu, also said that, following the changes, "will be created a super-immunity", and "the history of ANI cases will be thrown up for 25 MPs". The Superior Council of Magistracy has criticized changes to the Penal Code, emphasizing that it hadn't receive them for approval, as required by law.{{cite news |url=http://www.romanialibera.ro/actualitate/justitie/presedintele-csm-modificarile-codului-penal-ii-avantajeaza-pe-politicienii-penali-320336.html |title=Președintele CSM: Modificările Codului Penal îi avantajează pe politicienii penali |newspaper=România Liberă |date=12 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} Legal Committee of the Chamber of Deputies said in a statement that it had no obligation to seek the opinion of SCM. The [[Democratic Liberal Party (Romania)|Democratic Liberal Party]] submitted, on 12 December, to the [[Constitutional Court of Romania|Constitutional Court]], two notices about the changes adopted Tuesday by the Chamber of Deputies to the Penal Code, one aimed at defining civil servant and the other one referring to the conflict of interest.{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-politic-16191972-pdl-contestat-curtea-constitutionala-modificarile-aduse-codului-penal.htm |title=PDL a contestat la Curtea Constituțională modificările aduse Codului penal |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author1=Alina Neagu |author2=Luminița Pîrvu |date=12 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} Likewise, the High Court of Cassation and Justice notified the Constitutional Court on the same subject.{{cite news |url=http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/instanta-suprema-a-sesizat-curtea-constitutionala-cu-privire-la-modificarile-aduse-codului-1072177.html |title=Instanța Supremă a sesizat Curtea Constituţională cu privire la modificările aduse Codului penal |newspaper=Evenimentul Zilei |author =Virgil Burlă |date=12 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} The concerns expressed by about 50 PDL lawmakers were confirmed by the [[Constitutional Court of Romania]]. So, on 15 January 2014, the members of the Constitutional Court unanimously decided that the amendments to the Penal Code are unconstitutional.{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/ccr-a-decis-modificarile-aduse-codului-penal-neconstitutionale-superimunitatea-respinsa_1358573.html |title=CCR a decis: Modificările aduse Codului Penal, Neconstituționale. Superimunitatea, Respinsă |newspaper=Realitatea.net |date=15 January 2014 |language=Romanian}} CCR judges decided that the article which removes the officials from the category of public servants breaches several articles of the Constitution concerning the [[rule of law]], the equal rights of citizens and the Romanian State's obligation to fulfill in good faith its obligations in international treaties.{{cite news |url=http://www.gandul.info/stiri/curtea-constitutionala-respinge-superimunitatea-parlamentarilor-modificarile-la-codul-penal-neconstitutionale-11904171 |title=Curtea Constituțională respinge Superimunitatea Parlamentarilor. Modificările la Codul Penal, neconstituționale |newspaper=Gândul |author1=Biro Attila |author2=Sorina Ionașc |date=15 January 2014 |language=Romanian}} In a press conference, PSD deputy Eugen Nicolicea rejected accusations on new Penal Code, saying that press masked the truth.{{cite news |url=http://www.antena3.ro/politica/eugen-nicolicea-acuzatiile-privind-modificarile-codului-penal-sunt-false-237917.html |title=Eugen Nicolicea: Acuzațiile privind modificările Codului Penal sunt False |newspaper=Antena 3 |date=15 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} ===== International ===== * {{flagicon|USA}} In a meeting of the Chamber of Deputies, U.S. Embassy sent a very harsh reaction to the changes of the Penal Code. "This action of Parliament represents a departure from the principles of transparency and the rule of law and is a discouraging signal to investors, that will adversely affect the economy of Romania".{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-16183032-reactie-dura-ambasadei-sua-fata-modificarea-codului-penal-pas-napoi-pentru-romnia-ndepartare-principiile-transparentei-ale-statului-drept-este-semnal-descurajator-pentru-investitori-care-afecta-negati.htm |title=Reacții internaționale dure față de modificarea Codului Penal. Poziția Comisiei Europene, a Ambasadei SUA, Germaniei, Marii Britanii și Olandei/"Un pas înapoi pentru România, o îndepărtare de la principiile transparenței și ale statului de drept, un semnal descurajator pentru investitori, care va afecta negativ economia României" |newspaper=HotNews.ro |author =Cristian Pantazi |date=11 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} The U.S. Ambassador to the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]], Daniel B. Baer, said, on 20 December, that the United States are concerned about the recent amendments to the Penal Code and warned that ratification of these amendments will result in weakening the [[rule of law]] in Romania.{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/sua-critica-dur-modificarea-codului-penal-statul-de-drept-va-fi-slabit_1344728.html |title=SUA critică dur modificarea Codului Penal: Statul de drept va fi slăbit |newspaper=Realitatea.net |date=20 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} * {{flagicon|EU}} Similar reactions also came from the [[European Commission]]. The European Commission warns that public officials, regardless of the institution they work for, must obey rules against conflict of interest and corruption. "This change was not raised at any time. From our point of view, it's a decision that we didn't expect", said Mark Stephen Gray, spokesman for the European Commission. * {{flagicon|UK}} British Ambassador to Bucharest, Martin Harris, says he is "worried" for changes to the Penal Code. "It is very discouraging that these changes were adopted without any consultation, any debate and any opportunity for the representatives of the judiciary authority and members of civil society to comment about the proposed amendments", shows the reaction of the embassy.{{cite news |url=http://www.digi24.ro/Stiri/Digi24/Actualitate/Stiri/Ambasada+SUA+despre+modificarea+Codului+Penal+O+indepartare+de+l |title=Modificarea Codului Penal. Ambasadele occidentale îi critică pe parlamentarii români |newspaper=Digi24.ro |date=11 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} * {{flagicon|Germany}} The German Embassy took a stand against the amendments to the Penal Code, announcing that seeks "with attention and concern the current legislative measures".{{cite news |url=http://www.romanialibera.ro/actualitate/politica/ambasada-germaniei-ingrijorata-de-modificarea-codului-penal-320259.html |title=Ambasada Germaniei, "îngrijorată" de modificarea Codului Penal |newspaper=România Liberă |date=11 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} * {{flagicon|Netherlands}} The Netherlands Embassy in Bucharest stated that seeks with concern the amendments to the Penal Code and expects the future developments.{{cite news |url=http://www.gandul.info/stiri/olanda-urmareste-cu-ingrijorare-amendamentele-la-codul-penal-care-dau-imunitate-parlamentarilor-11755156 |title=Olanda "urmărește cu îngrijorare" amendamentele la Codul Penal care dau imunitate parlamentarilor |newspaper=Gândul |author =Cătălina Mihai |date=11 December 2013 |language=Romanian}} * {{flagicon|Austria}} [[Hannes Swoboda]], the leader of the Socialists in the [[European Parliament]], stated for [[Radio France Internationale]] that the amendments to the Penal Code contravene the values of the EU and is a real step backwards for the country.{{cite news |url=http://adevarul.ro/news/politica/codul-penal-decizie-rea-ue-1_52a9c6bec7b855ff56a7abee/index.html |title=Swoboda: Modificarea Codul Penal contravine valorilor UE. Este un pas înapoi, o decizie rea pentru țară însăși |newspaper=Adevărul |author =Mădălina Mihalache |date=12 December 2013 |language=Romanian}}{{cite news |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/politic/swoboda-modificarea-codului-penal-contravine-valorilor-ue-e-un-pas-inapoi-o-decizie-rea-pentru-tara-insasi-11761260 |title=Swoboda: Modificarea Codului Penal contravine valorilor UE.
