mid-February 2014, the [[government of Romania|Romanian government]] entered into [[deadlock]] after PNL, constituent party of the government, announced the reshuffling of four ministers. [[Victor Ponta]] repeatedly refused [[Klaus Iohannis]]' proposal as Deputy Premier and Minister of Interior, fact that inflamed the spirits inside PNL.{{cite news |url=http://www.cotidianul.ro/ponta-refuza-in-continuare-sa-mearga-in-parlament-pentru-numirea-lui-klaus-iohannis-232572/ |title=Ponta refuză în continuare să meargă în Parlament pentru numirea lui Klaus Iohannis |newspaper=Cotidianul |author =Ioana Radu |date=21 February 2014 |language=Romanian}} Thus, on 25 February, PNL decided in an overwhelming majority to leave the ruling coalition.{{cite news |url=http://www.romania-insider.com/its-official-romanias-ruling-coalition-collapses-as-pnl-leaves-government-asks-pm-to-resign/116075/ |title=It's official: Romania's ruling coalition collapses as PNL leaves Government, asks PM to resign |newspaper=Romania-Insider.com |date=25 February 2014}} A day later, all PNL ministers resigned.{{cite news |url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/politic/live-ora-17-30-pe-stirileprotv-ro-premierul-victor-ponta-sustine-o-declaratie-de-presa-la-palatul-victoria.html |title=USL, divorț urât. Miniștrii liberali au demisionat, UDMR se pregătește să revină la guvernare. Lista interimarilor |newspaper=Știrile Pro TV |date=26 February 2014 |language=Romanian}} A major political conflict also erupted in August, when the Parliament adopted an emergency ordinance allowing local authorities to [[party switching|switch between political parties]] without sanctions. The event, marked in Romanian press as "Black Thursday"{{cite news |url=http://www.puterea.ro/politica/joia-neagra-guvernul-ponta-ataca-din-nou-democratia-99068.html |title=Joia Neagră. Guvernul Ponta atacă din nou democrația |newspaper=Puterea |author =Mioara Costin |date=28 August 2014 |language=Romanian}} – in analogy with "Black Tuesday", was criticized by embassies of United States and United Kingdom,{{cite web |url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/politic/ambasada-sua-critica-ordonanta-traseismului-politic-suntem-ingrijorati-in-legatura-cu-momentul-ales-de-guvern.html |title=Ambasada SUA critică ordonanța "traseismului politic": Suntem îngrijorați în legătură cu momentul ales de Guvern |work=Știrile Pro TV |date=28 August 2014 |language=Romanian}} but especially by opposition that accuses Victor Ponta of trying to defraud presidential election in November, reason for that the Liberal Christian Alliance, supported by the [[People's Movement Party]], threatens the government with a [[motion of censure]].{{cite news |url=http://www.gandul.info/politica/guvernul-ponta-amenintat-de-o-motiune-de-cenzura-13177351 |title=Guvernul Ponta, amenințat de o moțiune de cenzură |newspaper=Gândul |author =Florin Ghețău |date=31 August 2014 |language=Romanian}} According to those who initiated this law, the party switching is a solution to institutional stalemate after breakage of the USL in February. However, the GEO was declared by [[Constitutional Court of Romania|CCR]] unconstitutional.{{cite web |url=http://www.gandul.info/politica/ordonanta-traseistilor-neconstitutionala-ccr-pune-parlamentul-sa-decida-ce-se-intampla-cu-mandatele-alesilor-migratori-13725945 |title=Ordonanța Traseiștilor, Neconstituțională. CCR pune Parlamentul să decidă ce se întâmplă cu mandatele aleșilor migratori |work=Gândul |author1=Andrei Luca Popescu |author2=Otilia Ciocan |date=17 December 2014 |language=Romanian}} ==== "War of the palaces" ==== Known in Romanian press as "War of the palaces" ({{lang-ro|Războiul dintre palate}}){{cite news |url=http://www.enational.ro/news/politica/razboiul-penal-dintre-palate-393754.html/ |title=Războiul penal dintre Palate |newspaper=Ziarul Național |author =Ana-Maria Ludatser |date=14 April 2014 |language=Romanian}}{{cite news |url=http://www.romanialibera.ro/actualitate/politica/razboiul-intre-palate--episodul-ii-330901 |title=Războiul între Palate, episodul II |newspaper=România Liberă |author =Ioan Bujor |date=1 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} was a prolonged conflict between President [[Traian Băsescu]] and Prime Minister [[Victor Ponta]], the representatives of [[Cotroceni Palace]] and [[Victoria Palace]], respectively. In April 2014, conflict between the two has deepened and escalated to threats of imprisonment from both of them.{{cite news |url=http://www.cotidianul.ro/ponta-si-basescu-se-vad-unul-pe-altul-in-puscarie-235929/ |title=Ponta și Băsescu se văd unul pe altul în pușcărie |newspaper=Cotidianul |author =Ioana Radu |date=14 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} President Traian Băsescu said that if Victor Ponta will try to interfere in the justice risks ending up in the hands of prosecutors, who will not tolerate that.{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/traian-basescu-victor-ponta-risca-sa-ajunga-coleg-de-camera-cu-nastase-e-profund-corupt_1419994.html |title=Traian Băsescu: Victor Ponta riscă să ajungă coleg de cameră cu Năstase. E profund corupt |newspaper=Realitatea.net |date=13 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} He also stated that Ponta is deeply corrupt, and his election as president would be a great drama for Romania.{{cite news |url=http://www.digi24.ro/Stiri/Digi24/Actualitate/Politica/Traian+Basescu+Ar+fi+o+drama+pentru+Romania+ca+Victor+Ponta+sa+a |title=Traian Băsescu: Ar fi o dramă pentru România ca Victor Ponta să ajungă președinte |newspaper=Digi24.ro |date=13 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} In reply, Victor Ponta stated: „(...) I am absolutely convinced that Traian Băsescu will go to jail. I, who know that I have always respected the law, I have no fear”.{{cite news |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-politic-17036666-victor-ponta-depunem-plingere-penala-impotriva-lui-basescu-pentru-declaratiile-adresa-familiei-lui-gabriela-vrinceanu-firea-basescu-ajunge-inchisoare.htm |title=Victor Ponta: Depunem plângere penală împotriva lui Băsescu pentru declarațiile la adresa familiei Gabrielei Vrânceanu Firea. Băsescu va ajunge în închisoare |newspaper=HotNews.ro |date=14 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} In a TV show, President Traian Băsescu reacted to declarations of PSD senator, [[Gabriela Firea]], stating: „She better stays in her seat and would handle what happens on the estate of her husband. Because she could no longer find him at home, if she is not careful. I understand that in his parish enough bad things happen”.{{cite news |url=http://www.ziare.com/basescu/presedinte/basescu-mesaj-pentru-gabriela-firea-s-ar-putea-sa-nu-si-mai-gaseasca-sotul-intr-o-zi-acasa-1293552 |title=Băsescu, mesaj pentru Gabriela Firea: S-ar putea să nu-și mai găsească soțul într-o zi acasă |newspaper=Ziare.com |date=13 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} Victor Ponta quickly reacted to these statements by drawing up a penal complaint against President Traian Băsescu. In this complaint, the President is accused of [[blackmail]] and threat.{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/plangerea-penala-impotriva-lui-basescu-semnata_1421164.html |title=Plângerea PenalǎFd împotriva lui Băsescu a fost redactată și este semnată în Parlament |newspaper=Realitatea.net |date=15 April 2014 |language=Romanian}}{{cite news |url=http://www.evz.ro/ponta-am-finalizat-plangerea-penala-impotriva-lui-basescu-o-semnam-cu-totii-kelemen-hunor-nu-semneaza.html |title=Ponta: "Am finalizat plângerea penală împotriva lui Băsescu, o semnăm cu toții". Kelemen Hunor nu semnează |newspaper=Evenimentul Zilei |author =Andreea Udrea |date=15 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} European Socialist leader [[Sergey Stanishev]] condemned the statements made by Traian Băsescu, claiming that declarations to Gabriela Firea are provocative and inflammatory, and the suggestion that her husband could "disappear" is beyond the limits of decency.{{cite news |url=http://www.realitatea.net/stanisev-declaratiile-lui-basescu-la-adresa-gabrielei-firea-sunt-dincolo-de-limita-decentei_1421431.html |title=Stanișev: Declarațiile lui Băsescu la adresa Gabrielei |title=După scandalul Duicu, Ponta își mută biroul de la Palatul Victoria la Ministerul Apărării Naționale, cu "pază militară", ca să se ferească de Traficul de Influență |newspaper=Gândul |date=14 |url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/politic/ponta-duicu-nu-a-fost-la-mine-iar-pentru-a-evita-alte-inscenari-mi-am-mutat-biroul-la-mapn.html |title=Ponta: Duicu nu a fost la mine, iar pentru a evita alte înscenări, mi-am mutat biroul la MApN |newspaper=Știrile Pro TV |date=14 April 2014 |language=Romanian}}{{cite news |url=http://adevarul.ro/news/politica/victor-ponta-invitat-romania-tv-incepand-ora-2100-1_534c05c00d133766a8c7e0f0/index.html |title=Ponta și-a mutat biroul, după scandalul cu baronul Duicu: Va fi mai bine păzit la MApN. Mă aștept la mai multe înscenări |newspaper=Adevărul |author =Mădălina Mihalache |date=14 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} Journalists criticized the stultification of the scandal involving Prime Minister Victor Ponta, accusing him that he tries to move the discussion from concrete facts reported by DNA prosecutors in the plan of political conflict with Traian Băsescu and "press staging".{{cite news |url=http://www.gandul.info/politica/realitatea-paralela-pe-care-o-construieste-premierul-romaniei-la-televizor-dupa-scandalul-duicu-de-ce-fraza-dna-n-are-nicio-treaba-cu-asta-este-o-minciuna-12467054 |title=Realitatea paralelă pe care o construiește premierul României la televizor după Scandalul Duicu. De ce fraza "DNA n-are nicio treabă cu asta" este o minciună |newspaper=Gândul |author1=Biro Attila |author2=Clarice Dinu |date=15 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} Victor Ponta's movement from the Victoria Palace to the Ministry of Defence was also criticized by PNL President [[Crin Antonescu]], claiming that the Prime Minister "has lost control" and "mocks the country's institutions".{{cite news |url=http://www.gandul.info/politica/antonescu-dupa-ce-ponta-s-a-mutat-in-mapn-premierul-si-a-pierdut-controlul-cum-isi-permite-daca-este-in-toate-facultatile-sa-faca-asa-ceva-nici-ceausescu-nu-si-a-permis-12469106 |title=Antonescu, după ce Ponta s-a mutat în MApN: "Premierul și-a pierdut controlul. Cum își permite, dacă este în toate facultățile, să facă așa ceva? Nici Ceaușescu nu și-a permis" |newspaper=Gândul |date=15 April 2014 |language=Romanian}} ==== Presidential election protests ==== An apparent discrepancy between the number of polling stations and the estimated voters in most European countries (in Germany only five stations were open for more than 200,000 expats), voters saw this as an ideologically selective denial of exercising the right to vote.{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/romania/11249449/Romanian-presidential-election-does-Klaus-Iohanniss-victory-prove-social-media-can-win-an-election.html |title=Romanian presidential election: does Klaus Iohannis's victory prove social media can win an election? |work=The Telegraph |author =Ria Ivandic |date=24 November 2014}} This fact attracted Romanians' angry at Ponta's policies, who began a "campaign" of protests and civil demonstrations within the country and abroad. Protests first broke out on 8 November when thousands gathered in city squares in support of compatriots living abroad who were turned away as they tried to vote in the first round,{{cite web |url=http://mashable.com/2014/11/08/romania-election-protest/ |title=Thousands protest presidential election across Romania |work=Mashable |author =Brittany Levine |date=9 November 2014}} prompting Romania's foreign minister [[Titus Corlățean]] to resign.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/14/us-romania-election-protests-idUSKCN0IY29920141114 |title=Thousands protest in Romania ahead of presidential run-off vote |work=Reuters |date=14 November 2014}} Long queues and bureaucratic hurdles made the voting process lengthy at Romanian embassies across the [[European Union]] and elsewhere in the first round.{{cite web |url=http://www.euractiv.com/sections/elections/irregularities-cloud-romanian-election-runoff-309726 |title=Irregularities cloud Romanian election runoff |work=EurActiv |author =Andrei Schwartz |date=4 November 2014}} Many were unable to cast their ballots before voting ended.{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.com/2014/11/15/romania-sees-protests-ahead-of-elections/ |title=Romania sees protests ahead of elections |work=Euronews |date=15 November 2014}} The government has taken measures to ensure 16 November vote runs smoothly, increasing the number of voting booths and staff abroad. But it has not increased the number of polling stations, as Romanian diaspora groups had demanded.{{cite web |url=http://www.euractiv.com/sections/elections/romania-rocked-protests-ahead-presidential-election-runoff-309884 |title=Romania rocked by protests ahead of presidential election runoff |work=EurActiv |author =Andrei Schwartz |date=10 November 2014}} [[File:Alegerile prezidențiale românești din 16 noiembrie 2014 la München (2).webm|thumb|A video depicting potential voters waiting and protesting in [[Munich]], approximately one hour before the polls closed on 16 November]] A day before the presidential runoff, large demonstrations were held across the country, with 15,000 attendees in [[Cluj-Napoca]] and 5,000 in [[Timișoara]]. The protests targeted PSD candidate and PM [[Victor Ponta]], blamed for poor organization of the voting process in diaspora. The irregularities in the first round repeated in the runoff. Then, tens of thousands of Romanians abroad were attacked with [[baton (law enforcement)|baton]]s and [[tear gas]] by law enforcers, while voters forced the entrance into embassies to cast their vote. In [[Bucharest]], up to 20,000 people gathered to protest against Victor Ponta, destroying the electoral posters with him. To everyone's surprise,{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-chance-for-lasting-change-in-romania-1417114166 |title=A Chance for Lasting Change in Romania |work=The Wall Street Journal |author =Mark Gitenstein |date=27 November 2014}} ethnic German candidate [[Klaus Iohannis]] from PNL won the election with a comfortable margin,{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-11-16/ethnic-german-johannis-surges-to-romania-presidency-win.html |title=Romania Opposition Chief Johannis Wins Presidency |work=Bloomberg |author1=Andra Timu |author2=Edith Balazs |date=17 November 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.dw.de/romanias-iohannis-wins-ponta-concedes/a-18068398 |title=Romania's Iohannis wins, Ponta concedes |work=Deutsche Welle |date=16 November 2014}} despite the fact that Victor Ponta surpassed Iohannis in all polls. Iohannis celebrated the victory with demonstrators in [[University Square, Bucharest|University Square]]. The result of the vote was seen in media as a "small revolution", given that Victor Ponta controlled the government since 2012, and PSD is the largest party in the country.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-11-18/east-europe-elections-surprise-as-voters-reject-authority.html |title=East Europe Elections Surprise as Voters Reject Authority |work=Bloomberg |author =Zoltan Simon |date=18 November 2014}} ==== Protests against MP immunity ==== In March 2015, a dispute arouse between ruling alliance PSD–UNPR–PC and main opposition party, PNL. PSD majority in the Senate rejected the solicitation of [[National Anticorruption Directorate|DNA]] prosecutors of arresting PSD MP [[Dan Șova]] in a corruption case.{{cite web |url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/politic/ce-cadou-va-primi-fostul-ministru-de-finante-senatul-decide-soarta-lui-valcov-chiar-de-ziua-lui-dar-si-a-lui-dan-sova.html |title=Darius Vâlcov a fost reținut de DNA, în timp ce Dan Șova și-a păstrat imunitatea. Cine a prezis votul încă de sâmbătă |work=Știrile Pro TV |date=25 March 2015 |language=Romanian}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/politic/dan-sova-scapa-de-arestare-cererea-dna-de-incuviintare-a-retinerii-si-arestarii-nu-a-trecut-de-senat-14052340 |title=Dan Șova scapă de arestare. Cererea DNA de încuviințare a reținerii și arestării nu a trecut de Senat |work=Mediafax.ro |last=Postelnicu |first=Valentina |date=25 March 2015 |language=Romanian}}{{cite web |url=http://adevarul.ro/news/politica/senatorii-decid-trimit-Sova-valcov-arest-motive-scornit-psd-a-i-apara-1_5511b760448e03c0fdde1e26/index.html |title=Senatul l-a salvat pe Dan Șova de cătușe sfidând Constituția. Darius Vâlcov poate fi arestat. Senator PSD: Mai lăsați-mă cu Constituția! |work=Adevărul |last1=Mihalache |first1=Mădălina |last2=Zachmann |first2=Sebastian |date=25 March 2015 |language=Romanian}} Although the vote was detrimental to Șova (79 to 67), PSD senators made use of a provision in the Rules of the Senate, ignoring the [[Constitution of Romania|Constitution]]. The Rules of the Senate say that a decision is taken by majority of all members, not by the majority of members present. Thus, by this interpretation, DNA needed 85 votes in favor.{{cite web |url=http://www.gandul.info/politica/de-bunavestire-dna-a-cerut-dezlegare-la-pestii-mari-din-senat-valcov-poate-fi-arestat-sova-a-scapat-de-procurori-14049458 |title=De Bunavestire, DNA a cerut Dezlegare la peștii mari din Senat. Vâlcov poate fi arestat, Șova a scăpat de procurori |work=Gândul |last=Ionașc |first=Sorina |date=25 March 2015 |language=Romanian}} The interpretation of the law by PSD senators defies the Constitution, namely Article 76, which states that "Ordinary laws and resolutions shall be passed by a majority vote of members present in each Chamber".{{Cite web|url = http://www.constitutiaromaniei.ro/art-76-adoptarea-legilor-si-a-hotararilor/|title = Art. 76 – Adoptarea legilor şi a hotărârilor|date = |accessdate = |website = Constitution of Romania|publisher = |language = Romanian}} In this context, the [[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party]] intends to appeal to the [[Constitutional Court of Romania|Constitutional Court]] the decision of the Senate,{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-politic-19739171-pnl-vrea-conteste-curtea-constitutionala-votul-senatului-cazul-dan-sova.htm |title=PNL vrea să conteste la Curtea Constituțională decizia Senatului în cazul Dan Șova și cere alegeri anticipate |work=HotNews.ro |last=C. |first=I. |date=25 March 2015 |language=Romanian}} also demanding early elections.{{cite web |url=http://www.realitatea.net/scandal-pe-tema-votului-in-cazul-sova-pnl-ataca-la-ccr-decizia-senatului-si-cere-alegeri-anticipate_1661169.html |title=Scandal pe tema votului în cazul Șova. PNL atacă la CCR decizia Senatului și cere alegeri anticipate |work=Realitatea.net |date=25 March 2015 |language=Romanian}} The Constitutional Court was also appealed by President [[Klaus Iohannis]]{{Cite web|url = http://www.gandul.info/politica/iohannis-sesizeaza-curtea-constitutionala-dupa-ce-senatul-a-respins-cererea-dna-de-arestare-a-lui-sova-14061873|title = Iohannis sesizează Curtea Constituţională după ce Senatul a respins cererea DNA de arestare a lui Şova|date = 26 March 2015|accessdate = |website = Gândul|publisher = |last = Dinu|first = Clarice}} and the [[National Anticorruption Directorate]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.gandul.info/politica/dna-cere-sesizarea-ccr-dupa-votul-senatului-in-cazul-lui-dan-sova-14060582|title = DNA cere sesizarea CCR după votul Senatului în cazul lui Dan Şova|date = 26 March 2015|accessdate = |website = Gândul|publisher = |last = Ionaşc|first = Sorina|language = Romanian}} George Kent, main coordinator of anticorruption programs in the Bureau for Europe and Eurasia of the [[U.S. State Department]], criticized the decision, pointing that "justice must be able to judge".{{cite web |url=http://www.gandul.info/international/in-ziua-in-care-senatul-a-facut-scut-in-jurul-lui-sova-parlamentarii-nostri-primesc-un-mesaj-clar-din-partea-americanilor-lasati-justitia-sa-si-faca-treaba-14052617 |title=În ziua în care Senatul a făcut scut în jurul lui Șova, parlamentarii noștri primesc un mesaj clar din partea americanilor: Lăsați justiția să-și facă treaba! |work=Gândul |last=Matis |first=Alina |date=25 March 2015 |language=Romanian}} Moreover, British Embassy in Bucharest expressed its concern about vote in the case of Dan Șova, stressing that "no one is above the law".{{cite web |url=http://www.evz.ro/cazul-dan-sova-a-starnit-reactii-din-partea-marilor-ambasade-ce-spun-sua-marea-britanie-si-olanda.html |title=Cazul Dan Șova a stârnit reacții din partea marilor Ambasade. CE spun SUA, Marea Britanie și Olanda |work=Evenimentul Zilei |last=Vintilă |first=Carmen |date=25 March 2015 |language=Romanian}} The same position was taken by Klaus Iohannis, also stating that "quality of deputy, senator or minister should not give anyone immunity to justice".{{Cite web|url = http://www.realitatea.net/iohannis-nu-pot-sa-trec-cu-vederea-faptul-ca-parlamentul-a-blocat-din-nou-o-cerere-a-justi-iei_1661415.html|title = Iohannis: Nu pot să trec cu vederea faptul că Parlamentul a blocat din nou o cerere a justiției|date = 25 March 2015|accessdate = |website = Realitatea.net|publisher = |language = Romanian}} [[Netherlands]] Embassy stated that follows "with concern and surprise" developments concerning parliamentary immunity, especially in a context where political parties have pledged to fight corruption. Cultural figures of Romania, among them writer [[Mircea Cărtărescu]], demanded early elections and expressed their dissatisfaction with the vote.{{Cite web|url = http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-esential-19747760-mircea-cartarescu-nu-mai-poate-acest-parlament-nevoie-alegeri-anticipate.htm|title = Mircea Cartarescu: Ne asteptam ca o banda de infractori sa-l dea pe mana procurorilor pe unul de-al lor? E nevoie de alegeri anticipate|date = 26 March 2015|accessdate = |website = HotNews.ro|publisher = |last = P.|first = R.|language = Romanian}} Following a complaint lodged by PNL, judges of the Constitutional Court ascertained, on 6 May, that the Senate decision in Șova case is unconstitutional,{{cite web |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/cc-hotararea-senatului-in-cazul-solicitarii-dna-de-incuvintare-a-arestarii-lui-sova-neconstitutionala-14216118 |title=CC: Hotărârea Senatului în cazul solicitării DNA de încuviințare a arestării lui Șova, neconstituțională |work=Mediafax.ro |last=Ciocan |first=Otilia |date=6 May 2015 |language=Romanian}} because it was adopted pursuant to legal and regulation dispositions which contravened the provisions of Article 76 paragraph 2 of the Constitution.{{cite web |url=http://www.realitatea.net/ccr-decizie-in-cazul-ova-hotarea-data-de-senat-neconstitu-ionala_1691685.html |title=CCR, decizie în cazul Șova: Hotărârea dată de Senat, neconstituțională. Reacția lui Tăriceanu |work=Realitatea.net |date=6 May 2015 |language=Romanian}} === November 2015 protests === In 2015, following the [[Colectiv nightclub fire]], a [[2015_Romanian_protests|series of protests]] were held across Romania.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-romania-pm-profile-idUSKCN0ST1Y120151104 These resulted in the resignation of the Prime Minister at that time, [[Victor Ponta]]. Afterwards, on 10 November 2015, President [[Klaus Iohannis]] nominated [[Dacian Cioloș]] to be prime minister.https://www.reuters.com/article/romania-government-pm/romanias-president-picks-former-european-commissioner-ciolos-as-pm-designate-idUSL8N1352AA20151110 On 17 November 2017 the Parliament voted in favour of the nomination, which marked the beginning of the [[Cioloș Cabinet]].https://www.reuters.com/article/us-romania-government-vote/romanian-government-meant-to-tackle-corruption-wins-parliaments-backing-idUSKCN0T61KF20151117 == See also == * [[Corruption in Romania]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Navboxes |title=Articles and topics related to 2012–15 unrest in Romania |state=collapsed |list1= {{Anti-government protests in the 21st century}} {{Riots, protests and civil disorder in Romania}} {{Traian Băsescu}} {{Victor Ponta}}}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2012-15 unrest in Romania}} [[Category:2012 in Romania|Unrest]] [[Category:2012 protests|Romania]] [[Category:2013 in Romania|Unrest]] [[Category:2013 protests|Romania]] [[Category:2014 in Romania|Unrest]] [[Category:2014 protests|Romania]] [[Category:2015 in Romania|Unrest]] [[Category:2015 protests|Romania]] [[Category:Anti-austerity protests in the European Union|Romania]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Government crises|Romania]] [[Category:Labor disputes in Romania]] [[Category:Protests in Romania]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Romania]] [[Category:Student protests in Romania]]

{{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = | honorific_suffix = | image = Jan Lievens - Portrait of Anna Maria van Schurman.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Anna Maria van Schurman, by [[Jan Lievens]], 1649 | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1607|11|05}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|1678|5|4|1607|11|05}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = Dutch | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = Painting
Engraving
Poetry | movement = | spouse = | awards = | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = | module = }} [[File:Anna Maria van Schurman 1607-1678 Erfgoedcentrum Rozet 300 191 d 2 A-14.jpg|alt=Engraving of Anna Maria van Schurman|thumb|360x360px|Engraving of Anna Maria van Schurman]] '''Anna Maria van Schurman ''' (November 5, 1607 – May 4, 1678) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] painter, engraver, poet, and scholar, who is best known for her exceptional learning and her defence of [[female education]]. She was a highly educated woman, who excelled in art, music, and literature, and became proficient in fourteen languages, including Latin, Greek, Hebrew, Arabic, Syriac, Aramaic, and an Ethiopic language, as well as various contemporary European languages.{{Cite web|url=http://www.annamariavanschurman.org/about-anna-maria-van-schurman/|title=About Anna Maria van Schurman|website=www.annamariavanschurman.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-14}} ==Life== Van Schurman was born in [[Cologne]], a bright daughter of wealthy parents, Frederik van Schurman, from Antwerp (d. 1623) and Eva von Harff de Dreiborn. At four years old she could already read.[http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/houb005groo01_01/houb005groo01_01_0149.htm Anna Maria Schuurmans biography] in ''De groote schouburgh der Nederlantsche konstschilders en schilderessen'' (1718) by [[Arnold Houbraken]], courtesy of the [[Digital library for Dutch literature]] Between 1613 and 1615, her family moved to [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]], and about ten years later, they moved again, this time to Franeker, in Friesland. From about 11 years old, Schurman's father started teaching her Latin and other subjects along with his sons, an unusual decision at a time when girls in noble families were not generally tutored in the classics.[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/artists/71389 Anna Maria van Schurman] in the [[RKD]] To learn Latin she was given [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]] to read by her father. The private education and self-study was complemented through correspondence and discussions with notables such as [[André Rivet]] and [[Friedrich Spanheim]], both professors of [[Leiden University]], and the family's neighbour [[Gisbertus Voetius]], a professor at the [[University of Utrecht]].{{Cite book|title = Women Writing Latin: Early Modern Women Writing Latin |publisher=Routledge|date= 2014|authors=Laurie J. Churchill, Phyllis R. Brown & Jane E. Jeffrey|isbn=9781135377564|pages=217}} She also excelled at painting, paper-cutting, embroidery, and wood carving. After her father's death, the family moved back to Utrecht in 1626. In her 20s Schurman's home became a meeting point for intellectuals. Among her friends were [[Constantijn Huygens]], [[Johan van Beverwijck]], [[Jacob de Witt]], [[Cornelius Boy]], [[Margaret Godewijck]] and [[Utricia Ogle]].{{Cite book|title = Republic of Women: Rethinking the Republic of Letters in the Seventeenth Century |publisher=Cambridge University Press|date= 2012|author=Carol Pal|isbn=9781139510752|pages=60}} In the 1630s she studied engraving with [[Magdalena van de Passe]]. In 1634, due to her distinction in Latin, she was invited to write a poem for the opening of the [[University of Utrecht]]. In the poem she celebrated the city of Utrecht and the new University. She noted the potential for the university to help the city cope with the economic impacts of the floods and the shifting course of the river [[Rhine]]. But she also challenged the exclusion of women from the university. In response to her complaint the university authorities allowed her to attend professor Voetius' lectures.{{Cite book|title = Women Writing Latin: Early Modern Women Writing Latin |publisher=Routledge|date= 2014|authors=Laurie J. Churchill, Phyllis R. Brown & Jane E. Jeffrey|isbn=9781135377564|pages=271}} Thus, in 1636 she became the first female student at the university.{{Cite book|title=Women Classical Scholars: Unsealing the Fountain from the Renaissance to Jacqueline de Romilly|last=Frade|first=Sofia|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2016|isbn=9780198725206|editor-last=Wyles|editor-first=Rosie|location=Oxford|pages=|chapter=Ménage's Learned Ladies: Anne Dacier (1647-1720) and Anna Maria van Schurman (1607-1678)|editor-last2=Hall|editor-first2=Edith}} Women at that time were not permitted to study at a university in Protestant Netherlands and for the lectures she attended she sat behind a screen or in a curtained booth so that the male students could not see her.Van Beek 2010: 60 and n. 97, who points out that we know this from reports by Van Schurman's fellow students Descartes and Hoornbeeck. At the university she also studied Hebrew, Arabic, Chaldee, Syriac and Ethiopian. This made her the first woman to study at a Dutch university. Her interest in philosophy and theology, and her artistic talent contributed to her fame and reputation as the "Star of Utrecht". By the 1640s she was fluent in 14 languages and wrote in Latin, Greek, Hebrew, Italian, French, Arabic, Persian, Ethiopian, German and Dutch. According to her contemporary [[Pierre Yvon]], Schurman had an excellent command of mathematics, geography and astronomy. The pious young scholar appeared to have had a number of suitors. After his wife had died in 1631 [[Constantijn Huygens]] asked for Schurman's hand in marriage and wrote 10 poems in three languages to her in 1634. Huygens was teased by other Dutch intellectuals. Schurman's commitment to celibacy and her studies seemed to be unwavering. When she chose the phrase ''Amor Meus Crucifixus Est'' (''My Love Has Been Crucified'') as her motto, her intellectual friends were finally convinced that her choice not to marry was rooted in her piety, rather than her scholarship.{{Cite book|title = Republic of Women: Rethinking the Republic of Letters in the Seventeenth Century |publisher=Cambridge University Press|date= 2012|author=Carol Pal|isbn=9781139510752|pages=56}} Schurman also produced delicate engravings by using a diamond on glass, sculpture, wax modelling, and the carving of ivory and wood. She also painted, especially portraits, becoming the first known Dutch painter to use pastel in a portrait. She gained honorary admission to the [[Guild of Saint Luke|St. Luke Guild of painters]] in 1643, signalling public recognition of her art. Schurman corresponded with the Danish noblewoman [[Birgitte Thott]], who translated classical authors and religious writings. Thott's translation of [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]]'s philosophical works included a preface in which she agitated for women's right to study. Thott stated that she translated classical works because few women were able to read Latin. Schurman publicly praised Thott and called her the "tenth Muse of the North".{{Cite book|title = Women Writing Latin: Early Modern Women Writing Latin |publisher=Routledge|date= 2014|authors=Laurie J. Churchill, Phyllis R. Brown & Jane E. Jeffrey|isbn=9781135377564|pages=277}} Schurman through correspondence established a network of learned women across Europe. She corresponded in Latin and Hebrew with [[Dorothea Moore]], in Greek with [[Bathsua Makin]], in French, Latin and Hebrew with [[Marie de Gournay]] and [[Marie du Moulin]], in Latin and French with [[Elizabeth Stuart, Queen of Bohemia|Elizabeth of Bohemia]], and in Latin with [[Queen Christina of Sweden]]. A frequent topic in this correspondence was the education of women. Schurman in the correspondence expressed her admiration for educated women like [[Lady Jane Gray]] and [[Queen Elizabeth I]].{{Cite book|title = Women Writing Latin: Early Modern Women Writing Latin |publisher=Routledge|date= 2014|authors=Laurie J. Churchill, Phyllis R. Brown & Jane E. Jeffrey|isbn=9781135377564|pages=275}} An unauthorised version of Schurman's writings on women's education was published in 1638 in Paris under the title ''Dissertatio De Ingenii Muliebris ad Doctrinam, & meliores Litteras aptitudine''. As the unauthorised collection of her writings circulated, Schurman decided to publish an authoritative Latin treatise in 1641. In 1657 the treatise was published in English under the title ''The Learned Maid or, Whether a Maid may be a Scholar''.{{Cite book|title = Reading Early Modern Women: An Anthology of Texts in Manuscript and Print, 1550-1700|publisher=Psychology Press|date= 2004|author=Melissa Smith|isbn= 9780415966467|pages=79}} == The Labadists == [[File:AnnaMaria vanSchurman.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Self portrait, 1632]] In her 60s Schurman emerged as one of the principal leaders of the [[Labadists]].{{Cite book|title = Anna Maria Van Schurman, 'The Star of Utrecht': The Educational Vision and Reception of a Savante |publisher=Anne R. Larsen|date= 2014|author=Routledge|isbn=9781317180708|pages=65}} In the 1660s Schurman had become increasingly disillusioned with the [[Reformed Churches in the Netherlands]].{{Cite book|title = Anna Maria Van Schurman, 'The Star of Utrecht': The Educational Vision and Reception of a Savante |publisher=Anne R. Larsen|date= 2014|author=Routledge|isbn=9781317180708|pages=62}} She made the reformation of the church her goal. Aside from corresponding with ministers she travelled throughout the country and organised meetings with them. She lamented the lack of spiritual devotion, and "exhibits of the ecclesiastics" that occupied the church's pulpits.{{Cite book|title = Anna Maria Van Schurman, 'The Star of Utrecht': The Educational Vision and Reception of a Savante |publisher=Anne R. Larsen|date= 2014|author=Routledge|isbn=9781317180708|pages=63}} In 1661 Schurman's brother studied theology with the Hebrew scholar [[Johannes Buxtorf]] in Basel, and got to know about the defrocked French priest [[Jean de Labadie]]. He travelled to [[Geneva]] to meet him. In 1662 he corresponded with Schurman at length about Labadie's teachings. When Labadie and a small number of followers stopped over in Utrecht on the way to [[Middelburg]], they lodged in Schurman's house. Labadie became the pastor of [[Middelburg]], preaching [[millenarianism]], arguing for moral regeneration, and that believers should live apart from unbelievers. Schurman supported him, even when he was removed as a pastor. When in late 1669 Labadie settled in [[Amsterdam]] to establish a separatist church Schurman sold her house and part of her library. She joined Labadie's sectarian community.{{Cite book|title = Anna Maria Van Schurman, 'The Star of Utrecht': The Educational Vision and Reception of a Savante |publisher=Anne R. Larsen|date= 2014|author=Routledge|isbn=9781317180708|pages=64}} In March 1669 she had broke with the Reformed Church when she published a 10-page pamphlet ''On the Reformation necessary at present in the Church of Christ''. She denounced the church men for trampling on "celestial wisdom", arguing that the people of God should be separated from the "mondains" through "hatred of the world" and "divine love". A public smear campaign followed, Schurman was attacked by her intellectual friends, including Huygens and Voetius. Her writing style became forthright and confident. When the Labadists had to leave Amsterdam Schurman secured an invitation from her friend [[Princess Elisabeth of Bohemia]], who in 1667 had become abbess at the [[Lutheran]] ''Damenstift'' of [[Herford Abbey]]. The 50 Labadists lived there between 1670 and 1672. At Herdford Schurman continued her art work and the Labadists maintained a printing press. Schurman was referred to by the Labadists as ''Mama'', Labadie as ''Papa''. Rumours had it that Labadie and Schurman had married, however he married Lucia van Sommelsdijck. In 1772 the Labadists moved to [[Altona, Hamburg|Altona]] in [[Denmark]], Elisabeth of Bohemia had advocated on their behalf in correspondence with the King of Denmark. In 1673 Schurman published ''Eukleria, or Choosing the Better Part'', a reference to Luke 10:42 when Mary chooses the better part by sitting at the feet of Christ.{{Cite book|title = Anna Maria Van Schurman, 'The Star of Utrecht': The Educational Vision and Reception of a Savante |publisher=Anne R. Larsen|date= 2014|author=Routledge|isbn=9781317180708|pages=66}} In it she derided [[Gisbertus Voetius]]'s opposition to her admiration for [[Saint Paula]], a disciple of [[St Jerome]], who had helped to translate the [[Bible]] into [[Latin]]. Voetius argued that women should have a limited public role, anything else was feminine impropriety. ''Eukleria'' was well received by [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] and prominent prietists, including [[Johann Jacob Schütz]], [[Philipp Jakob Spener]] and [[Eleonore van Merlau]].{{Cite book|title = Anna Maria Van Schurman, 'The Star of Utrecht': The Educational Vision and Reception of a Savante |publisher=Anne R. Larsen|date= 2014|author=Routledge|isbn=9781317180708|pages=66–67}} When Labadie died in 1674 Schurman investigated the possibility of moving to [[England]], corresponding with the Latin scholar [[Lucy Hutchinson]] and the theologian [[John Owen (theologian)|John Owen]] on the matter. But the Labadists moved to the village Wieuwerd in [[Friesland]] and attracted numerous new members, including [[Maria Sibylla Merian]]. About 400 Labadists practiced absolute detachment from worldly values. They attempted to return to early church practices, sharing all property. In the final years of her life Schurman was housebound due to severe [[rheumatism]]. She continued to write, keeping up correspondence and working on the second part of ''Eukleria''. She died aged 70 in 1678.{{Cite book|title = Anna Maria Van Schurman, 'The Star of Utrecht': The Educational Vision and Reception of a Savante |publisher=Anne R. Larsen|date= 2014|author=Routledge|isbn=9781317180708|pages=67}} == Published writings == [[File:1659 van Schurman Learned Maid.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The title page and frontispiece of van Schurman's ''The learned maid'', printed in 1659.]] Many of Schurman's writings were published during her lifetime in multiple editions, however some of her writings have nevertheless been lost. Her most famous book was the ''Nobiliss. Virginis Annae Mariae a Schurman Opuscula Hebraea Graeca Latina et Gallica, Prosaica et Metrica'' (''Minor works in Hebrew, Greek, Latin and French in prose and poetry by the most noble Anne Maria van Schurman''). It was published 1648 by [[Friedrich Spanheim]], professor of theology at [[Leiden University]] through the Leiden-based publisher [[House of Elzevir|Elzeviers]]. Schurman's ''The Learned Maid or, Whether a Maid may be a Scholar'' had grown out of her correspondence on women's education with theologians and scholars across Europe. In it she advances [[Jane Grey]] as an example of the value of female education. Schurman argued that educating women in languages and the Bible will increase their love of God.{{Cite book|title = Reading Early Modern Women: An Anthology of Texts in Manuscript and Print, 1550-1700|publisher=Psychology Press|date= 2004|author=Melissa Smith|isbn= 9780415966467|pages=59}} While an increasing number of royal and wealthy families chose to educate their daughters, girls and women did not have formal access to education.{{Cite book|title = Equality and Non-Discrimination under International Law|publisher=Routledge|date= 2017|author=Stephanie Farrior|isbn= 9781351568036|pages=222}} Schurman argued that "A Maid may be a Scholar... The assertion may be proved both from the property of the form of this subject; or the rational soul: and from the very acts and effects themselves. For it is manifest that Maids do actually learn any arts and science."{{Cite book|title = The Concept of Woman|publisher=William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company|date= 2017|author=Sister Prudence Allen R.S.M.|isbn= 9780802868435|pages=302}} In arguing that women had rational souls she foreshadowed the [[Cartesianism|Cartesian]] argument for human reason, and it underpinned her assertion that women had a right to be educated. Schurman and [[René Descartes]] corresponded and while they disagreed on the interpretation of the Bible they both thought that reason was central in the human identity.{{Cite book|title = The Concept of Woman|publisher=William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company|date= 2017|author=Sister Prudence Allen R.S.M.|isbn= 9780802868435|pages=303}} ''The Learned Maid'' included correspondence with the theologian [[André Rivet]]. In her correspondence with Rivet Schurman explained that women such as [[Marie de Gournay]] had already proven that man and woman are equal, so she will not "bore her readers with repetition". Like Rivet, Schurman argued in ''The Learned Maid'' for education on the basis of moral grounds, because "ignorance and idleness cause vice". But Schurman also took the position that "whoever by nature has a desire for arts and science is suited to arts and science: women have this desire, therefore women are suited to arts and science". However, Schurman did not advocate for [[universal education]], or the education for women of the lower classes. She took the view that ladies of upper classes should have access to higher education. Schurman made the point that women could make a valuable contribution to society, and argued that it was also necessary for their happiness to study [[theology]], [[philosophy]] and the [[sciences]].{{Cite book|title = Women's History as Scientists: A Guide to the Debates|publisher=ABC-CLIO|date= 2003|author=Leigh Ann Whaley|isbn= 9781576072301|pages=68}} In reference to ''The Learned Maid'' Rivet cautioned her in a letter that "although you have shown us this with grace, your persuasions are futile... You may have many admirers, but none of them agree with you."{{Cite book|title = Women's History as Scientists: A Guide to the Debates|publisher=ABC-CLIO|date= 2003|author=Leigh Ann Whaley|isbn= 9781576072301|pages=69}} ==Published works== ''Incomplete list'' *"De Vitae Termino" (On the End of Life). Published in Leiden, 1639. Translated into Dutch as "Pael-steen van den tijt onses levens," published in Dordrecht, 1639. *"Dissertatio De Ingenii Muliebris ad Doctrinam, & meliores Litteras aptitudine." Paris, 1638, and Leiden, 1641. Translated into many languages, including Dutch, French (1646), and English (1659), entitled "The Learned Maid or, Whether a Maid may be a Scholar." :This work argued, using the mediaeval technique of [[syllogism]], that women should be educated in all matters but should not use their education in professional activity or employment and it should not be allowed to interfere in their domestic duties. For its time this was a radical position. *"Opuscula Hebraea, Graeca, Latina, Gallica: prosaica adque metrica." Utrecht, 1648. :This is an edition of her collected works, including correspondence in French, Latin, Greek and Hebrew, were published by the house of [[House of Elzevir|Elsevier]], edited by [[Friedrich Spanheim]], another disciple of Labadie. Volume was reprinted in 1650, 1652, 1723 and 1749.{{cite web|last1=Whipp|first1=Koren|title=Anna Maria van Schurman|url=http://www.projectcontinua.org/biographies/index/v_index/anna-maria-van-schurman/|website=Project Continua|accessdate=23 September 2014}} *"Eukleria seu Meliores Partis Electio" (Eucleria, or Choosing the Better Part). Published in Altona, 1673. Translated into Dutch and German. :This is a defense of her choice to follow Labadie and a theological tract. ==Tributes== [[Judy Chicago]]'s feminist artwork ''[[The Dinner Party]]'' (1979) features a place setting for van Schurman.[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/place_settings Place Settings]. Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved on 2015-08-06. A marble bust of van Schurman is in the atrium of the Tweede Kamer of the Dutch Parliament in [[The Hague]].{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} ==Further reading== *Pieta van Beek: ''The first female university student: A.M.van Schurman'', Utrecht 2010, 280p. [http://dspace.library.uu.nl/handle/1874/235540 free PDF] *Bo Karen Lee: ''I wish to be nothing'': the role of self-denial in the mystical theology of A. M. van Schurman in: ''Women, Gender and Radical Religion in Early Modern Europe.'' Ed. Sylvia Brown. Leiden: 2008, [https://books.google.com/books?id=wIyI0T4DVVgC&pg=pa189#v=onepage&q&f=false 27 S. online at google-books] *Katharina M. Wilson and Frank J. Warnke (eds.), ''Women Writers of the Seventeenth Century'', Athens: U. of Georgia Press, (1989) pp 164–185 *Mirjam de Baar et al. (eds.), ''Choosing the Better Part. Anna Maria van Schurman (1607-1678)'', Dordrecht, Boston, London: Kluwer Academic Publishers, (1996). *Mirjam de Baar: ''Gender, genre and authority in seventeenth-century religious writing: Anna Maria van Schurman and [[Antoinette Bourignon]] as contrasting examples'', [https://web.archive.org/web/20130719150521/http://theol.eldoc.ub.rug.nl/FILES/root/2009/Gender/Baar-Gender-genre.pdf 30p. free PDF] *Anne R. Larsen, "Anna Maria van Schurman, 'The Star of Utrecht': The Educational Vision and Reception of a Savante", [Women and Gender in the Early Modern World], Abingdon: Routledge, 2016. *Anna Maria van Schurman, ''Whether a Christian Woman Should Be Educated and Other Writing from Her Intellectual Circle'', ed and trans by Joyce Irwin, Chicago 1998, [https://books.google.com/books?id=UbHdWsdwG5EC&printsec=frontcover&hl=de#v=onepage&q&f=false online at google-books] *Lennep, J, Herman F. C. Kate, and W P. Hoevenaar. [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZQ9jAAAAcAAJ&lpg=PA30-IA116&ots=TxJXQWMdW0&dq=Galerij%20van%20beroemde%20nederlanders%20uit%20het%20tijdvak%20van%20Frederik%20Hendrik&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q&f=false Galerij Van Beroemde Nederlanders Uit Het Tijdvak Van Frederik Hendrik]. Utrecht: L.E. Bosch en Zoon, 1868. *Martine van Elk, ''Early Modern Women's Writing: Domesticity, Privacy, and the Public Sphere in England and the Dutch Republic'', Cham: Palgrave/Springer, 2017 . ==See also== *[[List of Orientalist artists]] *[[Orientalism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Sources=== *[http://www.annamariavanschurman.org annamariavanschurman.org] (by Pieta van Beek) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051119075210/http://home.infionline.net/~ddisse/schurman.html A.M.Schurman in "Other Women's Voices"] *[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/jan-lievens-portrait-of-anna-maria-van-schurman National Gallery – Jan Lievens' portrait of Anna Maria van Schurman] ==External links== {{commons category|Anna Maria van Schurman}} *{{prdl|57}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schurman, Anna Maria}} [[Category:1607 births]] [[Category:1678 deaths]] [[Category:17th-century Dutch poets]] [[Category:17th-century Dutch philosophers]] [[Category:17th-century engravers]] [[Category:17th-century German poets]] [[Category:17th-century women artists]] [[Category:17th-century Dutch women writers]] [[Category:17th-century writers]] [[Category:Classical scholars]] [[Category:Dutch Golden Age painters]] [[Category:Dutch women painters]] [[Category:Dutch women philosophers]] [[Category:Dutch women poets]] [[Category:Dutch women writers]] [[Category:Feminism and history]] [[Category:Feminist writers]] [[Category:German women philosophers]] [[Category:German women poets]] [[Category:Glass engravers]] [[Category:Orientalist painters]] [[Category:People from Cologne]] [[Category:People from Utrecht (city)]] [[Category:Protestant philosophers]] [[Category:Women engravers]] [[Category:Women printmakers]] [[Category:Women classical scholars]]

{{Infobox language |name=Arabela |nativename= ''Tapweyokwaka'' |states=[[Peru]] |ethnicity=500 Arabela (2002) |speakers=50 |date = 2002 |ref = e18 |nation = {{PER}} |familycolor=American |fam1=[[Zaparoan]] |fam2=Arabela–Andoa |iso3=arl |glotto=arab1268 |glottorefname=Arabela |notice=IPA }} '''Arabela''' is a nearly extinct [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] American [[language]] of the [[Zaparoan]] family spoken in two [[Peru]]vian villages in tropical forest along the Napo tributary of the [[Arabela river]]. Also known as '''Chiripuno''' and '''Chiripunu''', it is spoken by fewer than 50 people out of an ethnic population of about 500. Since there are so few speakers of Arabela left, its speakers speak either [[Spanish language|Spanish]] or [[Quechua language|Quechua]] as a [[second language]]. The [[literacy rate]] for Arabela as a [[first language]] is about 10–30%, and about 50–75% for a [[second language]]. It uses a [[subject–object–verb|SOV word order]]. Like all native languages in [[Peru]], it has an [[official language|official]] status in areas where it is spoken.{{cite web |url=http://pdba.georgetown.edu/Constitutions/Peru/per93reforms05.html |title= CONSTITUCION POLÍTICA DEL PERÚ 1993 |publisher= |date=February 17, 2006 |accessdate=2009-03-02 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090221165642/http://pdba.georgetown.edu/Constitutions/Peru/per93reforms05.html| archivedate= 21 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} Artículo 48º Son idiomas oficiales el castellano y, en las zonas donde predominen, también lo son el quechua, el aimara y las demás lenguas aborígenes, según la ley. ==The language and its speakers== Arabela is a language of the [[Zaparoan languages|Zaparoan]] family of languages. Zaparoan tongues were once widely spoken in the [[rain forest]] of north-eastern [[Peru]], but Zaparoan-speaking people have been decimated by diseases, wars with neighboring native groups, and by quasi-enslavement during the [[rubber boom]]. Most Zaparoan communities have [[language shift|shifted]] to [[Lamas Quechua]] or [[Spanish language|Spanish]], while others have been incorporated into [[Shuar people|Shuar]] groups. The few surviving Zaparoan languages are all severely endangered. Among those, Arabela is most closely related to [[Zaparo language|Zaparo]] (the only one still spoken), [[Andoa language|Andoa]] and [[Conambo language|Conambo]]. ==Current situation== The dominant languages of the area are [[Kichwa]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]], and they are both widely spoken by [[Arabela people|Arabelas]]. Kichwa has been the default language for native communities in the area since the rubber boom era, and has spread through trade mixed marriages. It is, however, losing ground to Spanish in the younger generations. The use of Arabela is restricted to a small elderly fraction of the population. The language is official per the [[Constitution of Peru]], but this did not stop its decline. There is no written literature in Arabela, but the language has been used in education by the Peruvian government, which has issued some school material in it. The [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] has been translated into Arabela in 1988.{{UDHR|arl|Arabela}} ==Dialectal divisions== There is no dialectal division among known Arabela speakers. A small group, called ''Pananuyuri'', separated from other Arabelas roughly a century ago. Their fate is unknown but they may have survived, in which case their dialect is likely to have somewhat diverged from the other speakers'.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} ==Phonology== The Arabela phonemic inventory is quite typical for a Zaparoan language. It has five [[place of articulation|places of articulation]] and a vowel inventory of five [[vowel]]s common within the family.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} ===Vowels=== {|class="wikitable" |+ '''[[Vowel]]s''' |- ! ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- align="center" | '''[[Close vowel|Close]]''' | {{IPA|i}} | {{IPA|u}} |- align="center" | '''[[Near-close vowel|Near-close]]''' | {{IPA|ɪ}} | |- align="center" | '''[[Mid vowel|Mid]]''' | | {{IPA|o}} |- align="center" | '''[[Open vowel|Open]]''' | {{IPA|a}} | |} ===Consonants=== {| class="wikitable" |+ '''[[Consonant]]s''' |- ! ![[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ![[Dental consonant|Dental]] /
[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ![[Postalveolar consonant|Postalveolar]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] ![[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- align="center" ![[Stop consonant|Stop]] | {{IPA|[p]}} | {{IPA|[t]}} | | {{IPA|[k]}} | |- align="center" ![[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | | {{IPA|[s]}} | {{IPA|[ʃ]}} | | {{IPA|[ɦ]}} |- align="center" ![[Nasal stop|Nasal]] | {{IPA|[m]}} | {{IPA|[n]}} | | | |- align="center" ![[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | {{IPA|[w]}} | | {{IPA|[j]}} | | |- align="center" ![[Trill consonant|Trill]] | | {{IPA|[r]}} | | | |} ==Morphology== ===The noun=== Arabela has no [[grammatical gender]] but for a few words, mostly describing persons, the sex can be specified by adding a suffix : *'''Cua niya-nu''' : my son *'''Cua niya-tu''' : my daughter Arabela has two [[grammatical number]]s, singular and plural. The plural is generally added by adding a suffix to the singular, the nature of this suffix varying according to the pluralized word. *'''tia''' : house yields '''tiaca''' : houses *'''maaji''' : woman, yields '''maajipohua''' : women *'''niyacoo''' : unmarried girl yields '''niyacoojori''' : unmarried girls. In a few cases, however, the plural can be formed through suffix substitution, or by using a different root altogether. *'''caya''' : man yields '''canuu''' *'''maanu''' : group yields '''maapue''' *'''nucua''' : mother yields '''nuhuocuaca''' A number of other words form their plural by removing a singular specific suffix *'''saijia''' stone yields '''sai''' stone ===Pronouns=== Arabela has a complex pronominal system, similar to the one of the other [[zaparoan languages]] and distinguishes between active and passive personal pronouns. Active pronouns act as subjects in independent clause and as objects in dependent ones. ====Personal pronouns==== {| class="wikitable" |+ '''[[Personal pronoun]]s''' |- ! !First singular !Second singular !Third singular !First plural inclusive !First plural exclusive !Second plural !Third plural |- align="center" !Independent clause subject | janiya
-nijiya | quiajaniya
quiaa
-quiaa | nojuajua
-Vri | paa
-pue
paajaniya | canaa | niajaniya
niaa | nojori | |- align="center" !Independent clause object |cua | quia | na
quinio | pa | canaa | nia | nojori
na
-no |} ====Anaphoric pronouns==== The verbal ending '''-no''' is used as an [[anaphora (linguistics)|anaphoric]]. It can also mark the subject of a subordinate sentence when it refers to the object of the main sentence. ====Demonstrative pronouns==== Arabela has three kinds of [[demonstrative pronoun]]s : * '''noo''' indicates an object close to the speaker * '''nio''' indicates an object further away from the speaker (''Nio-te quia panishano'' - is it what you want) * '''cuno''' indicates a contrast between objects or persons (''cuno-cuaja cua sare'' - this is my dog) ====Interrogative pronouns==== Arabela has a rather restricted of interrogative pronouns, composed of: * '''cana''' : who * '''canapue''' : who (plural) * '''casaa''' : what * '''taa''' : how, how much * '''taamueca''' : how * '''tee''' : where * '''teje''' : where from * '''teyano''' : who, which ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Dicconario Arabela—Castellano, Rolland G. Rich, Instituto Lingüistico de Verano, Perú – 1999 * Rich, Furne. 1963. "Arabela Phonemes and High-Level Phonology," SPIL I, 193-206 ==External links== *{{WALS|arb|Arabela}} *{{UDHR|arl|Arabela}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121011032453/http://www.sil.org/americas/peru/html/pubs/slp49.zip Dicconario Arabella—Castellano, Rolland G. Rich, Instituto Lingüistico de Verano, Perú – 1999] {{Languages of Peru}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arabela Language}} [[Category:Languages of Peru]] [[Category:Zaparoan languages]] [[Category:Subject–object–verb languages]] [[Category:Endangered indigenous languages of the Americas]]

[[Image:KingPumpkin.jpg|thumb|King Pumpkin of the Barnesville Pumpkin Festival in 2008]] The '''Barnesville Pumpkin Festival''' is an annual festival in [[Barnesville, Ohio]], dedicated to the growing and harvesting of [[pumpkin]]s and other fall harvests. The festival, which has been held since 1964, is conducted by a locally appointed committee and attracts an average of 100,000 people during the 4 day event.<ref>http://www.barnesvilleohio.com/ Barnesville, Ohio Website</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtov9.com/best9/11958301/detail.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090917101102/http://www.wtov9.com/best9/11958301/detail.html |archivedate=2009-09-17 |df= }}</ref>
==Dates== The Pumpkin Festival is held the last full week in September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ofea.org/view.php?fest_id%3D47 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307143751/http://www.ofea.org/view.php?fest_id=47 |archivedate=2009-03-07 |df= }}</ref> The official ribbon cutting is held on Thursday, but the local citizens are encouraged to preview the festival on Wednesday.
==Locations== The Pumpkin Festival begins preparations the Monday before the festival and restricted areas are placed from the center of town at the junction of Chestnut Street and Main Street, west along Main Street to the junction of Main Street and Gardner Street; and from where W. Church Street and N. Broadway Street meet, south to the junction of South Broadway and South Street. This however only comprises the downtown section, several other events and locations dot the town. There is abundant parking, but most is private and requires a parking and safety fee.
==History== The Barnesville Pumpkin Festival began in 1964 as the Ohio Fall Festival and was held in the basement of the Church of the Assumption. The name changed to the Ohio Pumpkin Festival and the event was held out of doors in the center of town in the 1970s and changed to the Barnesville Pumpkin Festival later that same decade.
== Traditions== The Barnesville Pumpkin Festival holds its annual weigh-in on the Wednesday preceding the event. The event has seen pumpkins with weights breaking and matching state and local records.<ref>http://www.timesleaderonline.com/page/content.detail/id/512770.html?nav=5010</ref> The King Pumpkin contenders are too heavy to be weighed on a conventional scale, weighing in at over 650kg (1400 lbs), and thus a local funeral home scale is used. The official ribbon cutting is held the following day and is done by either the committee president, city mayor, parade marshal or other notable local figure. The Annual Pumpkin Auction is held on the last day, Sunday, where the local business compete bids to display the winning pumpkin and sell off the seeds as they see fit.
The [[Olney Friends School]] is famous for bringing over 700 loaves of pumpkin bread to sell from their booth, baked by the students.
There are many games, rides, and other activities set up during the festival. Some of the usual rides are the G-Force, The Pumpkin Ride, The Umbrellas, and the Monkey Cages.
==See also== *[[Circleville Pumpkin Show]]

Italy | language = English | budget = 250,000,000 lire{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/variety168-1947-12|title=Variety (December 1947)|first=|last=Variety|date=7 April 2018|publisher=New York, NY: Variety Publishing Company|via=Internet Archive}} ($1.5 million{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/variety168-1947-11|title=Variety (November 1947)|first=|last=Variety|date=7 April 2018|publisher=New York, NY: Variety Publishing Company|via=Internet Archive}}) | gross = }} '''''Black Magic''''' is a 1949 [[film adaptation]] of [[Alexandre Dumas]]'s novel ''Joseph Balsamo''. It was directed by the Russian-born [[Gregory Ratoff]]. Set in the 18th century, the film stars [[Orson Welles]] in the lead role as [[Joseph Balsamo]], a [[hypnotist]], [[Illusionist|magician]], and [[charlatan]] who also goes by the alias Count Cagliostro, and [[Nancy Guild]] as Lorenza/[[Marie Antoinette]]. [[Akim Tamiroff]] has a featured role. == Plot == Alexandre Dumas, Sr. ([[Berry Kroeger]]) tells his son [[Alexandre Dumas, fils|Alexandre Dumas, Jr.]] ([[Raymond Burr]]) the story of Joseph Balsamo ([[Orson Welles]]) aka Cagliostro. Through [[Flashback (narrative)|flashbacks]] we learn that Balsamo was a French [[Fictional representations of Romani people|gypsy]] boy who endured much hardship. He was tortured under the command of Viscount de Montagne ([[Stephen Bekassy]]) and his parents were ordered to hang. He was rescued by some gypsies led by Gitano and swears revenge on de Montagne. Some years later, he learns the secrets of [[hypnosis]] from [[Franz Mesmer|Dr. Mesmer]] ([[Charles Goldner]]). Ignoring the doctor's advice that he use his powers for healing, he exploits his new talent to the full, gaining [[wealth]], [[celebrity|fame]] and prestige. After changing his name to Count Cagliostro, he becomes famous throughout Europe. Things begin to go downhill when he enters a plot to substitute a young girl called Lorenza ([[Nancy Guild]]) for Queen [[Marie Antoinette]] along with gypsies Gitano ([[Akim Tamiroff]]) and Zoraida ([[Valentina Cortese]]). The plot is organised by de Montagne in association with Madame du Barry. They plan for Lorenza to impersonate the Queen and buy a frivolous necklace. Zoraida becomes jealous of Lorenza, who has fallen under Cagliostro's power, forgetting her true love, Gilbert. Gilbert runs away with Lorenza. Cagliostro recaptures her and marries her, hypnotised. King Louis XV dies and Marie Antoinette becomes queen. She orders Cagliosto to leave the country. Cagliostro gets Lorenza to impersonate the Queen and pretend to be in love with de Montagne. He buys the necklace and the queen's reputation is damaged. Zoraida brings Lorenza to Marie Antoinette and reveals Cagliostro's plot. Lorenza agrees to testify against Cagliostro, but at the trial, Cagliostro hypnotizes her into stating that she knows nothing. Cagliostro hypnotizes Gilbert into testifying against the queen. However, Memser then uses the necklace to hypnotize Cagliostro into confessing. Cagliostro awakens from his trance and escapes with the hypnotized Lorenza. Gilbert pursues them and kills Cagliostro in a sword fight. == Cast == {{div col}} * [[Orson Welles]] as Joseph Balsamo a.k.a. Count Cagliostro * [[Nancy Guild]] as Marie Antoinette / Lorenza * [[Akim Tamiroff]] as Gitano * [[Frank Latimore]] as Captain Gilbert de Rezel * [[Valentina Cortese]] as Zoraida * [[Margot Grahame]] as [[Madame du Barry]] * Stephen Bekassy as Viscount de Montagne * [[Berry Kroeger]] as Alexandre Dumas, Sr. * [[Gregory Gaye]] as Chambord / Monk * [[Raymond Burr]] as Alexandre Dumas, Jr. * Charles Goldner as Dr. Franz Anton Mesmer * Lee Kresel as King Louis XVI / Innkeeper * [[Robert Atkins (actor)|Robert Atkins]] as King Louis XV * Nicholas Bruce as De Remy * Franco Corsaro as Chico * Annielo Mele as Joseph Balsamo, as a child * [[Ronald Adam (actor)|Ronald Adam]] as Court President * [[Bruce Belfrage]] as Crown Prosecutor * Alexander Danaroff as Dr. Duval / Baron von Minden * Leonardo Scavino as Gaston / Beniamino Balsamo * [[Tamara Shayne]] as Maria Balsamo * Joop van Hulzen as Minister of Justice * Peter Trent as Dr. Mesmer's Friend * Giuseppe Varni as Boehmer * [[Tatyana Pavlova]] as The mother {{div col end}} ==Production== The movie was originally known as ''Cagliostro''. Producer [[Edward Small]] went through a number of directors and stars in trying to get this film off the ground, starting in 1943.DRAMA AND FILM: Ann Blyth Adolescent Song Joust Contender College Professor Battling Illiterates; 'Cagliostro' Once Again Coming to Life Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 14 June 1943: 14. [[Charles Boyer]] was to star with Akim Tamiroff, and [[Irving Pichel]] directing, then in early 1944 [[J. Carrol Naish]] was reported to play Alexandre Dumas, Sr. Later that year, [[George Sanders]] was announced as the star with [[Douglas Sirk]] directing.Andy Russell Touted as Mexico's Sinatra: Bing Crosby Will Fill Guest-Star Spot in Filmization of 'Duffy's Tavern' Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 01 Sep 1944: 10. [[Louis Hayward]] was also at one stage announced to star.HOLLYWOOD HITS JAPS: East and West Old Londontown VARIED HOLLYWOOD ACTIVITIES One Down, More to Go Title Problem By FRED STANLEY. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 11 Feb 1945: X1 In 1943 [[Hedda Hopper]] suggested Orson Welles should play the lead role.Looking at Hollywood.... Hopper, Hedda. Chicago Daily Tribune (1923-1963) [Chicago, Ill] 02 July 1943: 17 He signed in September 1947.CAGLIOSTRO' LEAD TO ORSON WELLES: Small Signs Actor for Film to Be Made in Italy With an American Cast By THOMAS F. BRADY Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 22 Sep 1947: 28. In 1947, Small was to make the film in Mexico, but dropped those plans when it turned out to be more expensive to shoot there than he expected – so the location of shooting was changed to Italy, where Small could use blocked lira.BURLESQUE' AGAIN TO BE MADE A FILM: Fox Purchases Screen Rights to 1928 Play -- Jessel Named to Produce New Version By THOMAS F. BRADY New York Times 6 Sep 1947: 11. Small borrowed [[Gregory Ratoff]], [[Frank Latimore]] and Nancy Guild from [[Twentieth Century-Fox]] and took over the Scalera studios in Rome from early October 1947 to late January 1948.Europe Becomes Merely 'Location' to Hollywood Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 08 Feb 1948: D1.HISTORIC 'SET': Poor Benefit by Use of Roman Church in Film Rome. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 16 Jan 1949: X4 Charles Bennett, who wrote the script, said [[Jose Ferrer]] was supposed to play the lead but he demanded a three picture contract from Small who refused. Bennett later said Ratoff and Welles rewrote the film, but he admired Welles' performance. [[Orson Welles]] said Small ("no mean master of suggestion, by the way") approached him "very cleverly with the role of Cagliostro. He waited til I had reread the Dumas novels and become so 'hypnotised' by the scoundrel that I felt I had to play him. Then Small announced casually, '[[Gregory Ratoff]] is going to direct'. That cinched it. Gregory is a great friend, and more fun to work with than anybody I know."OUT OF A TRANCE By ORSON WELLES. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 17 Apr 1949: X4. United Artists were so enthusiastic about the film they agreed to distribute the film for 25% of the profits as opposed to their usual fee of 27 1/2%.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/variety173-1949-03|title=Variety (March 1949)|first=|last=Variety|date=7 April 2018|publisher=New York, NY: Variety Publishing Company|via=Internet Archive}} Welles allegedly directed several scenes in the film, which was released on 18 August 1949.{{tcmdb title|68897|Black Magic}} ==Reception== Reviews were mixed.All Over Town T. M. P.. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 09 Nov 1949: 37.Orson Welles Pulls Mass Hypnosis Act on Us All Scheuer, Philip K. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 19 Aug 1949: B5. The 2006 film [[Fade to Black (2006 film)|''Fade to Black'']] has Welles ([[Danny Huston]]) involved in a murder mystery while in Rome for the production of ''Black Magic''. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0041182|Black Magic}} * {{tcmdb title|68897|Black Magic}} * {{Amg movie|5897|Black Magic}} * {{AFI film|id=27707|title=Black Magic}} {{Gregory Ratoff}} {{Orson Welles}} {{Edward Small}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Magic (1949 film)}} [[Category:1949 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Gregory Ratoff]] [[Category:Films directed by Orson Welles]] [[Category:Films based on French novels]] [[Category:Films based on works by Alexandre Dumas]] [[Category:Films set in France]] [[Category:Films set in the 18th century]] [[Category:Films about Marie Antoinette]] [[Category:Works about Alessandro Cagliostro]] [[Category:Works about the Affair of the Diamond Necklace]] [[Category:Works about Louis XV of France]] [[Category:Films featuring hypnosis]] [[Category:Fictional representations of Romani people]] [[Category:Films about Alessandro Cagliostro]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Madame du Barry]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Louis XV]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Louis XVI]]

{{Infobox language |name=Bonda |altname=Remo |region=[[India]] |speakers=9,000 |date=2002 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Austroasiatic |fam2=[[Munda languages|Munda]] |fam3=[[Koraput]] |fam4=Remo |script=[[Odia alphabet|Odia]]<ref>{{Ethnologue18|bfw}}</ref> |iso3=bfw |glotto=bond1245 |glottorefname=Bondo }}
The '''Bonda language''', also known as '''Bondo''' or '''Remo''', is an indigenous language spoken in [[Odisha]], formerly known as Southern Odisha, in [[India]].<ref name=":0" /> It had 2,568 speakers, all in Odisha, according to the 1951 Census of India,<ref name="LSI">N. Gopalakrishnan, ''[http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011-Documents/LSI/lsi_Orissa/18_orissa_vol_page_no_257_272.pdf Linguistic Survey of India]'', p. 271</ref> increasing to approximately 9,000 speakers in 2002 according to [[SIL International|SIL]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/18/language/bfw/|title=Bondo|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2017-05-04}}</ref>
==Classification== The Bonda language is an indigenous language belonging to the Southern subgroup of the [[Munda languages|Munda]] branch of the [[Austroasiatic languages|Austroasiatic language family]].<ref name="e18" /> Bonda is a [[spoken language]] with no traditional written system recorded. Bonda is a part of the Gutob-Remo branch, due to the similarities Bonda shares with another Southern Munda Language named [[Gutob language|Gutob]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Munda Languages|last=Anderson|first=Gregory|publisher=Routledge|year=2008|isbn=9780415328906|location=New York|pages=557–631}}</ref>
==History== The Bonda language derives its name from the tribe of the [[Bonda people]], an indigenos group located in Odisha known as the Bonda Highlanders. In their native language, the Bonda people regard themselves as "Remo', which translates to human, and derive their language name from that root, calling their language as the human language or 'Remosam' in their native tongue<ref>{{Cite book|title=Tribal and Indigenous People of India: Problems and Prospects|last=Dash|first=Jagannatha|last2=Pati|first2=Rabindra|publisher=APH Publishing Corperation|year=2002|isbn=8176483222|location=New Delhi|pages=136–144}}</ref>
==Geographic distribution== The language differs slightly, classified according to whether it can be categorized as Plains Remo (Bonda) or Hill Remo (Bonda).<ref name=":0" />
===Plains Remo=== This is a subdivision of Bonda, localized in 35 villages throughout the Khairpat within the [[Malkangiri district]] in Odisha. In 1941, 2,565 people categorized the Plains Remo. That number nearly doubled in 1971, with 4,764 people classifying themselves as Plains Remo. The increase in population was not correlated with language extension.<ref name=":0" /> There are 3,500 speakers as of 2002, but few are monolingual.<ref name=":2" />
===Hills Remo=== This is a subdivision of Bonda, localized in the Jeypore Hills region of Odisha.<ref name=":0" /> There are 5,570 speakers as of 2002.<ref name=":2" />
==Phonology== ===Stress=== In Bonda, [[primary stress]] is placed on the last syllable in a word, syllables with [[diphthong]]s, [[glottal stop]]s, or checked consonants.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Swain|first=Rajashree|date=1998|title=A Grammar of Bonda Language|jstor=42930587|journal=Bulletin of the Deccan College Research Institute|volume=58/59|pages=391–396}}</ref> However, Plains Remo primarily stresses the second syllable in a word.<ref name=":0" /> Bonda words can have a maximum of 5 syllables.<ref name=":1" />
===Diphthongs=== Diphthongs are placed either in the beginning or middle of a word, usually used in combination of two different vowel types.<ref name=":1" /> {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible" !Bonda !Translation<ref name=":0" /> |- |''lean'' |tongue |- |''bois'' |age |- |''guidag'' |to wash |- |''otoi'' |not to be |- |''dau'' |small |}
===Consonants=== There are 33 consonants in the Bonda language.<ref name=":1" /> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+Consonants<ref name=":4" /> ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" | ! colspan="2" |[[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! colspan="2" |[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! colspan="2" |[[Retroflex consonant|Retroflex]] ! colspan="2" |[[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! colspan="2" |[[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- !<small>plain</small> ![[Aspirated consonant|<small>aspirated</small>]] !<small>plain</small> ![[Aspirated consonant|<small>aspirated</small>]] !<small>plain</small> ![[Aspirated consonant|<small>aspirated</small>]] !<small>plain</small> ![[Aspirated consonant|<small>aspirated</small>]] !<small>plain</small> ![[Aspirated consonant|<small>aspirated</small>]] |- ! rowspan="2" |[[Stop consonant|Stop]] !<small>voiceless</small> |p |pʰ |t |tʰ |ʈ |ʈʰ |c |cʰ |k |kʰ |ʔ |- ![[Voice (phonetics)|<small>voiced</small>]] |b |bʱ |d |dʱ |ɖ |ɖʱ |ɟ |ɟʱ |g |gʱ | |- ! rowspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] !<small>voiceless</small> | | |s | | | | | | | |h |- ![[Voice (phonetics)|<small>voiced</small>]] | | |(z) | | | | | | | | |- ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] |m | |n | |ɳ | |ɲ | |ŋ | | |- ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | |l | |ɭ | |j | |w | | |- ! colspan="2" |[[Trill consonant|Trill]] | | |r | | | | | | | | |} /z/ only occurs in loanwords from [[Odia language|Odia]]. <ref name=":1" />
===Vowels=== Bonda has 5 vowel [[phoneme]]s: /a, e, i, o, u/.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=DeArmond|first=Richard|date=1976|title=Proto-Gutob-Remo-Gtaq Stressed Monosyllabic Vowels and Initial Consonants|jstor=20019157|journal=Oceanic Linguistics Special Publications|volume=13|pages=213–217}}</ref>
In Bonda, vowels are [[Nasalization|nasalized]] and [[Vowel cluster|clusters]] are commonplace.<ref name=":1" />
==Grammar== ===Syntax=== Bonda follows the [[Subject–object–verb|SOV]] (Subject + Object + Verb) sequence, but other word orders are possible.<ref name=":1" />
=== Gender === Age and gender serve as classification denominations for individuals. Female names end in /-i/ and male names end in /-a/. Animals are also distinguished by gender.<ref name=":1" />
===Compound Verb=== The [[compound verb]] is not frequently used in Bonda and can be used as a conjunctive participle.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hook|first=Peter|date=1991|title=The Compound Verb in Munda: An Areal and Typological Overview|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/038800019190013Q|journal=Language Sciences|volume=13|pages=181–195|doi=10.1016/0388-0001(91)90013-Q}}</ref>
==Vocabulary== === Kinship Terminology === In Kinship terms, the [[velar nasal]], ŋ, is often used. Various kinship terms also represent multiple positions.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Bhattacharya|first=Sudhibhushan|date=1970|title=Kinship Terms in the Munda Language|journal=Anthropos|volume=65|pages=444–465|jstor=40457389}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable mw-collapsible" !Bonda !English Gloss<ref name=":3" /> |- |''baʔ'' |Father |- |''iyɔŋ'' |Mother |- |''remɔ'' |Man |- |''mpɔr'' |Husband |- |''kunui'' |Wife |- |''bɔrai'' |Aunt |- |''busã'' |Uncle |- |''tata'' |Grandfather |- |''ya/iya'' |Father's Mother/Mother's Mother |- |''maŋ'' |Eldest brother |- |''miŋ'' |Elder sister |- |''ileʔǐ'' |Grandchild |- |''masɔ'' |Nephew |}
